play.title:
THE LIFE OF TYMON
OF ATHENS.

act.stagedir: Enter Pœt, Painter, Ieweller, Merchant, and Mercer, at ſeuerall doores.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: Good day Sir.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: I am glad y’are well.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: I haue not ſeene you long, how gœs
the World?

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: It weares ſir, as it growes.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: I that’s well knowne:
But what particular Rarity? What ſtrange,
Which manifold record not matches: ſee
Magicke of Bounty, all theſe ſpirits thy power
Hath coniur’d to attend.
I know the Merchant.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: I know them both: th’others a Ieweller.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: O ’tis a worthy Lord.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: Nay that’s moſt ﬁxt.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: A moſt incomparable man, breath’d as it were,
To an vntyreable and continuate goodneſſe:
He paſſes.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: I haue a Iewell heere.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: O pray let’s ſee’t. For the Lord Timon, ſir?

speech.speaker: Iewel.
speech.line: If he will touch the eſtimate. But for that—

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: When we for recompence haue prais’d the vild,
It ſtaines the glory in that happy Verſe,
Which aptly ſings the good.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: ’Tis a good forme.

speech.speaker: Iewel.
speech.line: And rich: heere is a Water looke ye.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: You are rapt ſir, in ſome worke, ſome Dedica-
tion to the great Lord.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: A thing ſlipt idlely from me.
Our Pœſie is as a Gowne, which vſes
From whence ’tis nouriſht: the ﬁre i’th’ Flint
Shewes not, till it be ſtrooke: our gentle ﬂame
Prouokes it ſelfe, and like the currant ﬂyes
Each bound it chaſes. What haue you there?

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: A Piƈture ſir: when comes your Booke forth?

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: Vpon the heeles of my preſentment ſir.
Let’s ſee your peece.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: ’Tis a good Peece.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: So ’tis, this comes off well, and excellent.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: Indifferent.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: Admirable: How this grace
Speakes his owne ſtanding: what a mentall power
This eye ſhootes forth? How bigge imagination
Moues in this Lip, to th’dumbneſſe of the geſture,
One might interpret.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: It is a pretty mocking of the life:
Heere is a touch: Is’t good?

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: I will ſay of it,
It Tutors Nature, Artiﬁciall ſtrife
Liues in theſe toutches, liuelier then life.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: How this Lord is followed.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: The Senators of Athens, happy men.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: Looke mœ.

speech.speaker: Po.
speech.line: You ſee this conﬂuence, this great ﬂood of viſitors,
I haue in this rough worke, ſhap’d out a man
Whom this beneath world doth embrace and hugge
With ampleſt entertainment: My free driﬅ
Halts not particularly, but moues it ſelfe
In a wide Sea of wax, no leuell’d malice
Infeƈts one comma in the courſe I hold,
But ﬂies an Eagle ﬂight, bold, and forth on,
Leauing no Traƈt behinde.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: How ſhall I vnderſtand you?

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: I will vnboult to you.
You ſee how all Conditions, how all Mindes,
As well of glib and ſlipp’ry Creatures, as
Of Graue and auſtere qualitie, tender downe
Their ſeruices to Lord Timon: his large Fortune,
Vpon his good and gracious Nature hanging,
Subdues and properties to his loue and tendance
All ſorts of hearts; yea, from the glaſſe-fac’d Flatterer
To Apemantus, that few things loues better
Then to abhorre himſelfe; euen hee drops downe
The knee before him, and returnes in peace
Moſt rich in Timons nod.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: I ſaw them ſpeake together.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: Sir, I haue vpon a high and pleaſant hill
Feign’d Fortune to be thron’d.
The Baſe o’th’ Mount
Is rank’d with all deſerts, all kinde of Natures
That labour on the boſome of this Sphere,
To propagate their ſtates; among’ſt them all,
Whoſe eyes are on this Soueraigne Lady ﬁxt,
One do I perſonate of Lord Timons frame,
Whom Fortune with her Iuory hand waﬅs to her,
Whoſe preſent grace, to preſent ſlaues and ſeruants
Tranſlates his Riuals.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: ’Tis conceyu’d, to ſcope
This Throne, this Fortune, and this Hill me thinkes
With one man becken’d from the reſt below,
Bowing his head againſt the ſleepy Mount
To climbe his happineſſe, would be well expreſt
In our Condition.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: Nay Sir, but heare me on:
All thoſe which were his Fellowes but of late,
Some better then his valew; on the moment
Follow his ſtrides, his Lobbies ﬁll with tendance,
Raine Sacriﬁciall whiſperings in his eare,
Make Sacred euen his ſtyrrop, and through him
Drinke the free Ayre.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: I marry, what of theſe?

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: When Fortune in her ſhiﬅ and change of mood
Spurnes downe her late beloued; all his Dependants
Which labour’d aﬅer him to the Mountaines top,
Euen on their knees and hand, let him ſit downe,
Not one accompanying his declining foot.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: Tis common: A thouſand morall Paintings I can ſhew,
That ſhall demonſtrate theſe quicke blowes of Fortunes,
More pregnantly then words. Yet you do well,
To ſhew Lord Timon, that meane eyes haue ſeene
The foot aboue the head.

act.stagedir: Enter Lord Timon, addreſſing himſelfe curteouſly to euery Sutor.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Impriſon’d is he, ſay you?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: I my good Lord, ﬁue Talents is his debt,
His meanes moſt ſhort, his Creditors moſt ſtraite:
Your Honourable Letter he deſires
To thoſe haue ſhut him vp, which failing,
Periods his comfort.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Noble Ventidius, well:
I am not of that Feather, to ſhake off
My Friend when he muſt neede me. I do know him
A Gentleman, that well deſerues a helpe,
Which he ſhall haue. Ile pay the debt, and free him.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Your Lordſhip euer bindes him.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Commend me to him, I will ſend his ranſome,
And being enfranchized bid him come to me;
’Tis not enough to helpe the Feeble vp,
But to ſupport him aﬅer. Fare you well.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: All happineſſe to your Honor.Exit.

speech.speaker: Oldm.
speech.line: Lord Timon, heare me ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Freely good Father.

speech.speaker: Oldm.
speech.line: Thou haſt a Seruant nam’d Lucilius.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I haue ſo: What of him?

speech.speaker: Oldm.
speech.line: Moſt Noble Timon, call the man before thee.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Attends he heere, or no? Lucillius.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Heere at your Lordſhips ſeruice.

speech.speaker: Oldm.
speech.line: This Fellow heere, L. Timon, this thy Creature,
By night frequents my houſe. I am a man
That from my ﬁrſt haue beene inclin’d to thriﬅ,
And my eſtate deſerues an Heyre more rais’d,
Then one which holds a Trencher.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Well: what further?

speech.speaker: Old.
speech.line: One onely Daughter haue I, no Kin elſe,
On whom I may conferre what I haue got:
The Maid is faire, a’th’ youngeſt for a Bride,
And I haue bred her at my deereſt coſt
In Qualities of the beſt. This man of thine
Attempts her loue: I prythee (Noble Lord)
Ioyne with me to forbid him her reſort,
My ſelfe haue ſpoke in vaine.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: The man is honeſt.

speech.speaker: Oldm.
speech.line: Therefore he will be Timon,
His honeſty rewards him in it ſelfe,
It muſt not beare my Daughter.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Dœs ſhe loue him?

speech.speaker: Oldm.
speech.line: She is yong and apt:
Our owne precedent paſſions do inſtruƈt vs
What leuities in youth.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Loue you the Maid?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I my good Lord, and ſhe accepts of it.

speech.speaker: Oldm.
speech.line: If in her Marriage my conſent be miſſing,
I call the Gods to witneſſe, I will chooſe
Mine heyre from forth the Beggers of the world,
And diſpoſſeſſe her all.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: How ſhall ſhe be endowed,
If ſhe be mated with an equall Husband?

speech.speaker: Oldm.
speech.line: Three Talents on the preſent; in future, all.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: This Gentleman of mine
Hath ſeru’d me long:
To build his Fortune, I will ſtraine a little,
For ’tis a Bond in men. Giue him thy Daughter,
What you beſtow, in him Ile counterpoize,
And make him weigh with her.

speech.speaker: Oldm.
speech.line: Moſt Noble Lord,
Pawne me to this your Honour, ſhe is his.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: My hand to thee,
Mine Honour on my promiſe.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Humbly I thanke your Lordſhip, neuer may
That ſtate or Fortune fall into my keeping,
Which is not owed to you.Exit

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: Vouchſafe my Labour,
And long liue your Lordſhip.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I thanke you, you ſhall heare from me anon:
Go not away. What haue you there, my Friend?

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: A peece of Painting, which I do beſeech
Your Lordſhip to accept.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Painting is welcome.
The Painting is almoſt the Naturall man:
For ſince Diſhonor Trafﬁckes with mans Nature,
He is but out-ſide: Theſe Penſil’d Figures are
Euen ſuch as they giue out. I like your worke,
And you ſhall ﬁnde I like it; Waite attendance
Till you heare further from me.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: The Gods preſerue ye.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Well fare you Gentleman: giue me your hand.
We muſt needs dine together: ſir your Iewell
Hath ſuffered vnder praiſe.

speech.speaker: Iewel.
speech.line: What my Lord, diſpraiſe?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: A meere ſaciety of Commendations,
If I ſhould pay you for’t as ’tis extold,
It would vnclew me quite.

speech.speaker: Iewel.
speech.line: My Lord, ’tis rated
As thoſe which ſell would giue: but you well know,
Things of like valew differing in the Owners,
Are prized by their Maſters. Beleeu’t deere Lord,
You mend the Iewell by the wearing it.

speech.speaker: Tim
speech.line: Well mock’d. Enter Apermantus.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: No my good Lord, he ſpeakes ӳ common toong
Which all men ſpeake with him.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Looke who comes heere, will you be chid?

speech.speaker: Iewel.
speech.line: Wee’l beare with your Lordſhip.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Hee’l ſpare none.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Good morrow to thee,
Gentle Apermantus.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Till I be gentle, ſtay thou for thy good morrow.
When thou art Timons dogge, and theſe Knaues honeſt.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Why doſt thou call them Knaues, thou know’ſt
them not?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Are they not Athenians?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Then I repent not.

speech.speaker: Iew.
speech.line: You know me, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Thou know’ſt I do, I call’d thee by thy name.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Thou art proud Apemantus?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Of nothing ſo much, as that I am not like Timon

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Whether art going?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: To knocke out an honeſt Athenians braines.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: That’s a deed thou’t dye for.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Right, if doing nothing be death by th’Law.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: How lik’ſt thou this piƈture Apemantus?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: The beſt, for the innocence.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Wrought he not well that painted it.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: He wrought better that made the Painter, and
yet he’s but a ﬁlthy peece of worke.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: Y’are a Dogge.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Thy Mothers of my generation: what’s ſhe, if I
be a Dogge?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Wilt dine with me Apemantus?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: No: I eate not Lords.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: And thou ſhould’ſt, thoud’ſt anger Ladies.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: O they eate Lords;
So they come by great bellies.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: That’s a laſciuious apprehenſion.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: So, thou apprehend’ſt it,
Take it for thy labour.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: How doſt thou like this Iewell, Apemantus?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Not ſo well as plain-dealing, which wil not caſt
a man a Doit.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: What doſt thou thinke ’tis worth?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Not worth my thinking.
How now Pœt?

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: How now Philoſopher?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Thou lyeſt.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: Art not one?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: Then I lye not.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Art not a Pœt?

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Then thou lyeſt:
Looke in thy laſt worke, where thou haſt fegin’d him a
worthy Fellow.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: That’s not feign’d, he is ſo.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Yes he is worthy of thee, and to pay thee for thy
labour. He that loues to be ﬂattered, is worthy o’th ﬂat-
terer. Heauens, that I were a Lord.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: What wouldſt do then Apemantus?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: E’ne as Apemantus dœs now, hate a Lord with
my heart.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: What thy ſelfe?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: I.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Wherefore?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: That I had no angry wit to be a Lord.
Art not thou a Merchant?

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: I Apemantus.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Trafﬁck confound thee, if the Gods will not.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: If Trafﬁcke do it, the Gods do it.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Trafﬁckes thy God, & thy God confound thee.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: What Trumpets that?

speech.speaker: Mes.
speech.line: ’Tis Alcibiades, and ſome twenty Horſe
All of Companionſhip.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Pray entertaine them, giue them guide to vs.
You muſt needs dine with me: go not you hence
Till I haue thankt you: when dinners done
Shew me this peece, I am ioyfull of your ſights.
Moſt welcome Sir.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: So, ſo; their Aches contraƈt, and ſterue your
ſupple ioynts: that there ſhould bee ſmall loue amongeſt
theſe ſweet Knaues, and all this Curteſie. The ſtraine of
mans bred out into Baboon and Monkey.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: Sir, you haue ſau’d my longing, and I feed
Moſt hungerly on your ſight.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Right welcome Sir:
Ere we depart, wee’l ſhare a bounteous time
In different pleaſures.
Pray you let vs in.Exeunt.

speech.speaker: 1.Lord
speech.line: What time a day is’t Apemantus?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Time to be honeſt.
That time ſerues ſtill.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: The moſt accurſed thou that ſtill omitſt it.
Thou art going to Lord Timons Feaſt.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: I, to ſee meate ﬁll Knaues, and Wine heat fooles.
Farthee well, farthee well.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Thou art a Foole to bid me farewell twice.
Why Apemantus?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Should’ſt haue kept one to thy ſelfe, for I meane
to giue thee none.
Hang thy ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: No I will do nothing at thy bidding:
Make thy requeſts to thy Friend.
Away vnpeaceable Dogge,
Or Ile ſpurne thee hence.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: I will ﬂye like a dogge, the heeles a’th’Aſſe.
Hee’s oppoſite to humanity.
Come ſhall we in,
And raſte Lord Timons bountie: he out-gœs
The verie heart of kindneſſe.
He powres it out: Plutus the God of Gold
Is but his Steward: no meede but he repayes
Seuen-fold aboue it ſelfe: No guiﬅ to him,
But breeds the giuer a returne: exceeding
All vſe of quittance.
The Nobleſt minde he carries,
That euer gouern’d man.
Long may he liue in Fortunes. Shall we in?
Ile keepe you Company.Exeunt.

act.stagedir: A great Banquet ſeru’d in: and then, Enter Lord Timon, the States, the Athenian Lords, Ventigius which Timon redeem’d from priſon. Then comes dropping aﬅer all Apemantus diſcontentedly like himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Ventig.
speech.line: Moſt honoured Timon,
It hath pleas’d the Gods to remember my Fathers age,
And call him to long peace:
He is gone happy, and has leﬅ me rich:
Then, as in gratefull Vertue I am bound
To your free heart, I do returne thoſe Talents
Doubled with thankes and ſeruice, from whoſe helpe
I deriu’d libertie.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: O by no meanes,
Honeſt Ventigius: You miſtake my loue,
I gaue it freely euer, and ther’s none
Can truely ſay he giues, if he receiues:
If our betters play at that game, we muſt not dare
To imitate them: faults that are rich are faire.

speech.speaker: Vint.
speech.line: A Noble ſpirit.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Nay my Lords, Ceremony was but deuis’d at ﬁrſt
To ſet a gloſſe on faint deeds, hollow welcomes,
Recanting goodneſſe, ſorry ere ’tis ſhowne:
But where there is true friendſhip, there needs none.
Pray ſit, more welcome are ye to my Fortunes,
Then my Fortunes to me.

speech.speaker: 1.Lord.
speech.line: My Lord, we alwaies haue confeſt it.

speech.speaker: Aper.
speech.line: Ho ho, confeſt it? Handg’d it? Haue you not?

speech.speaker: Timo.
speech.line: O Apermantus, you are welcome.

speech.speaker: Aper.
speech.line: No: You ſhall not make me welcome:
I come to haue thee thruſt me out of doores.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Fie, th’art a churle, ye’haue got a humour there
Dœs not become a man, ’tis much too blame:
They ſay my Lords, Ira furor breuis eſt,
But yond man is verie angrie.
Go, let him haue a Table by himſelfe:
For he dœs neither affeƈt companie,
Nor is he ﬁt for’t indeed.

speech.speaker: Aper.
speech.line: Let me ſtay at thine apperill Timon,
I come to obſerue, I giue thee warning on’t.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I take no heede of thee: Th’art an Athenian,
therefore welcome: I my ſelfe would haue no power,
prythee let my meate make thee ſilent.

speech.speaker: Aper.
speech.line: I ſcorne thy meate, ’twould choake me: for I
ſhould nere ﬂatter thee. Oh you Gods! What a number
of men eats Timon, and he ſees ’em not? It greeues me
to ſee ſo many dip there meate in one mans blood, and
all the madneſſe is, he cheeres them vp too.
I wonder men dare truſt themſelues with men.
Me thinks they ſhould enuite them without kniues,
Good for there meate, and ſafer for their liues.
There’s much example for’t, the fellow that ſits next him,
now parts bread with him, pledges the breath of him in
a diuided draught: is the readieſt man to kill him. ’Tas
beene proued, if I were a huge man I ſhould feare to
drinke at meales, leaſt they ſhould ſpie my wind-pipes
dangerous noates, great men ſhould drinke with harneſſe
on their throates.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: My Lord in heart: and let the health go round.

speech.speaker: 2.Lord.
speech.line: Let it ﬂow this way my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Aper.
speech.line: Flow this way? A braue fellow. He keepes his
tides well, thoſe healths will make thee and thy ſtate
looke ill, Timon.
Heere’s that which is too weake to be a ſinner,
Honeſt water, which nere leﬅ man i’th’ mire:
This and my food are equals, there’s no ods,
Feaſts are to proud to giue thanks to the Gods.

line.italic: Immortall Gods, I craue no pelfe,
I pray for no man but my ſelfe,
Graunt I may neuer proue ſo fond,
To truſt man on his Oath or Bond.
Or a Harlot for her weeping,
Or a Dogge that ſeemes aſleeping,
Or a keeper with my freedome,
Or my friends if I ſhould need ’em.
Amen. So fall too’t:
Richmen ſin, and I eat root.

act.line: Much good dich thy good heart, Apermantus

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Captaine,
Alcibiades, your hearts in the ﬁeld now.

speech.speaker: Alci.
speech.line: My heart is euer at your ſeruice, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: You had rather be at a breakefaſt of Enemies,
then a dinner of Friends.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: So they were bleeding new my Lord, there’s no
meat like ’em, I could wiſh my beſt friend at ſuch a Feaſt.

speech.speaker: Aper.
speech.line: Would all thoſe Flatterers were thine Enemies
then, that then thou might’ſt kill ’em: & bid me to ’em.

speech.speaker: 1.Lord.
speech.line: Might we but haue that happineſſe my Lord,
that you would once vſe our hearts, whereby we might
expreſſe ſome part of our zeales, we ſhould thinke our
ſelues for euer perfeƈt.

speech.speaker: Timon.
speech.line: Oh no doubt my good Friends, but the Gods
themſelues haue prouided that I ſhall haue much helpe
from you: how had you beene my Friends elſe. Why
haue you that charitable title from thouſands? Did not
you chiefely belong to my heart? I haue told more of
you to my ſelfe, then you can with modeſtie ſpeake in
your owne behalfe. And thus farre I conﬁrme you. Oh
you Gods (thinke I,) what need we haue any Friends; if
we ſhould nere haue need of ’em? They were the moſt
needleſſe Creatures liuing; ſhould we nere haue vſe for
’em? And would moſt reſemble ſweete Inſtruments
hung vp in Caſes, that keepes there ſounds to them-
ſelues. Why I haue oﬅen wiſht my ſelfe poorer, that
I might come neerer to you: we are borne to do bene-
ﬁts. And what better or properer can we call our owne,
then the riches of our Friends? Oh what a pretious com-
fort ’tis, to haue ſo many like Brothers commanding
one anothers Fortunes. Oh ioyes, e’ne made away er’t
can be borne: mine eies cannot hold out water me thinks
to forget their Faults. I drinke to you.

speech.speaker: Aper.
speech.line: Thou weep’ſt to make them drinke, Timon.

speech.speaker: 2.Lord.
speech.line: Ioy had the like conception in our eies,
And at that inſtant, like a babe ſprung vp.

speech.speaker: Aper.
speech.line: Ho, ho: I laugh to thinke that babe a baſtard.

speech.speaker: 3.Lord.
speech.line: I promiſe you my Lord you mou’d me much.

speech.speaker: Aper.
speech.line: Much.

act.stagedir: Sound Tucket. Enter the Maskers of Amazons, with Lutes in their hands, dauncing and playing.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: What meanes that Trumpe? How now?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Pleaſe you my Lord, there are certaine Ladies
Moſt deſirous of admittance.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Ladies? what are their wils?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: There comes with them a fore-runner my Lord,
which beares that ofﬁce, to ſigniﬁe their pleaſures.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I pray let them be admitted.

act.stagedir: Enter Cupid with the Masks of Ladies.

speech.speaker: Cup.
speech.line: Haile to thee worthy Timon and to all that of
his Bounties taſte: the ﬁue beſt Sences acknowledge thee
their Patron, and come freely to gratulate thy plentious
boſome.
There taſt, touch all, pleas’d from thy Table riſe:
They onely now come but to Feaſt thine eies.

speech.speaker: Timo.
speech.line: They’r welcome all, let ’em haue kind admit-
tance. Muſicke make their welcome.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: You ſee my Lord, how ample y’are belou’d.

speech.speaker: Aper.
speech.line: Hoyday,
What a ſweepe of vanitie comes this way.
They daunce? They are madwomen,
Like Madneſſe is the glory of this life,
As this pompe ſhewes to a little oyle and roote.
We make our ſelues Fooles, to diſport our ſelues,
And ſpend our Flatteries, to drinke thoſe men,
Vpon whoſe Age we voyde it vp agen
With poyſonous Spight and Enuy.
Who liues, that’s not depraued, or depraues;
Who dyes, that beares not one ſpurne to their graues
Of their Friends guiﬅ:
I ſhould feare, thoſe that dance before me now,
Would one day ſtampe vpon me: ’Tas bene done,
Men ſhut their doores againſt a ſetting Sunne.

act.stagedir: The Lords riſe from Table, with much adoring of Timon, and to ſhew their loues, each ſingle out an Amazon, and all Dance, men with women, a loﬅie ſtraine or two to the Hoboyes, and ceaſe.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: You haue done our pleaſures
Much grace (faire Ladies)
Set a faire faſhion on our entertainment,
Which was not halfe ſo beautifull, and kinde:
You haue added worth vntoo’t, and luſter,
And entertain’d me with mine owne deuice.
I am to thanke you for’t.

speech.speaker: 1 Lord.
speech.line: My Lord you take vs euen at the beſt.

speech.speaker: Aper.
speech.line: Faith for the worſt is ﬁlthy, and would not hold
taking, I doubt me.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Ladies, there is an idle banquet attends you,
Pleaſe you to diſpoſe your ſelues.

speech.speaker: All La
speech.line: Moſt thankfully, my Lord.Exeunt.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Flauius.

speech.speaker: Fla.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: The little Casket bring me hither.

speech.speaker: Fla.
speech.line: Yes, my Lord. More Iewels yet?
There is no croſſing him in’s humor,
Elſe I ſhould tell him well, yfaith I ſhould;
When all’s ſpent, hee’ld be croſt then, and he could:
’Tis pitty Bounty had not eyes behinde,
That man might ne’re be wretched for his minde.Exit.

speech.speaker: 1 Lord.
speech.line: Where be our men?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Heere my Lord, in readineſſe.

speech.speaker: 2 Lord.
speech.line: Our Horſes.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: O my Friends:
I haue one word to ſay to you: Looke you, my good L.
I muſt intreat you honour me ſo much,
As to aduance this Iewell, accept it, and weare it,
Kinde my Lord.

speech.speaker: 1 Lord.
speech.line: I am ſo farre already in your guiﬅs.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: So are we all.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: My Lord, there are certaine Nobles of the Senate
newly alighted, and come to viſit you.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: They are fairely welcome.

speech.speaker: Fla.
speech.line: I beſeech your Honor, vouchſafe me a word, it
dœs concerne you neere.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Neere? why then another time Ile heare thee.
I prythee let’s be prouided to ſhew them entertainment.

speech.speaker: Fla.
speech.line: I ſcarſe know how.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: May it pleaſe your Honor, Lord Lucius
(Out of his free loue) hath preſented to you
Foure Milke-white Horſes, trapt in Siluer.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I ſhall accept them fairely: let the Preſents
Be worthily entertain’d.
How now? What newes?

speech.speaker: 3.Ser.
speech.line: Pleaſe you my Lord, that honourable Gentle-
man Lord Lucullus, entreats your companie to morrow,
to hunt with him, and ha’s ſent your Honour two brace
of Grey-hounds.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Ile hunt with him,
And let them be receiu’d, not without faire Reward.

speech.speaker: Fla.
speech.line: What will this come to?
He commands vs to prouide, and giue great guiﬅs, and
all out of an empty Coffer:
Nor will he know his Purſe, or yeeld me this,
To ſhew him what a Begger his heart is,
Being of no power to make his wiſhes good.
His promiſes ﬂye ſo beyond his ſtate,
That what he ſpeaks is all in debt, he ows for eu’ry word:
He is ſo kinde, that he now payes intereſt for’t;
His Land’s put to their Bookes. Well, would I were
Gently put out of Ofﬁce, before I were forc’d out:
Happier is he that has no friend to feede,
Then ſuch that do e’ne Enemies exceede.
I bleed inwardly for my Lord.Exit

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: You do your ſelues much wrong,
You bate too much of your owne merits.
Heere my Lord, a triﬂe of our Loue.

speech.speaker: 2.Lord.
speech.line: With more then common thankes
I will receyue it.

speech.speaker: 3.Lord.
speech.line: O he’s the very ſoule of Bounty.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: And now I remember my Lord, you gaue good
words the other day of a Bay Courſer I rod on. Tis yours
becauſe you lik’d it.

speech.speaker: 1.L.
speech.line: Oh, I beſeech you pardon mee, my Lord, in that.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: You may take my word my Lord: I know no
man can iuſtly praiſe, but what he dœs affeƈt. I weighe
my Friends affeƈtion with mine owne: Ile tell you true,
Ile call to you.

speech.speaker: All Lor.
speech.line: O none ſo welcome.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I take all, and your ſeuerall viſitations
So kinde to heart, ’tis not enough to giue:
Me thinkes, I could deale Kingdomes to my Friends,
And nere be wearie. Alcibiades,
Thou art a Soldiour, therefore ſildome rich,
It comes in Charitie to thee: for all thy liuing
Is mong’ſt the dead: and all the Lands thou haſt
Lye in a pitcht ﬁeld.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: I, deﬁl’d Land, my Lord.

speech.speaker: 1.Lord.
speech.line: We are ſo vertuouſly bound.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: And ſo am I to you.

speech.speaker: 2.Lord.
speech.line: So inﬁnitely endeer’d.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: All to you. Lights, more Lights.

speech.speaker: 1.Lord.
speech.line: The beſt of Happines, Honor, and Fortunes
Keepe with you Lord Timon.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Ready for his Friends.Exeunt Lords

speech.speaker: Aper.
speech.line: What a coiles heere, ſeruing of beckes, and iut-
ting out of bummes. I doubt whether their Legges be
worth the ſummes that are giuen for ’em.
Friendſhips full of dregges,
Me thinkes falſe hearts, ſhould neuer haue ſound legges.
Thus honeſt Fooles lay out their wealth on Curtſies.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Now Apermantus (if thou wert not ſullen)
I would be good to thee.

speech.speaker: Aper.
speech.line: No, Ile nothing; for if I ſhould be brib’d too,
there would be none leﬅ to raile vpon thee, and then thou
wouldſt ſinne the faſter. Thou giu’ſt ſo long Timon (I
feare me) thou wilt giue away thy ſelfe in paper ſhortly.
What needs theſe Feaſts, pompes, and Vaine-glories?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Nay, and you begin to raile on Societie once, I
am ſworne not to giue regard to you. Farewell, & come
with better Muſicke.Exit

speech.speaker: Aper.
speech.line: So: Thou wilt not heare mee now, thou ſhalt
not then. Ile locke thy heauen from thee:
Oh that mens eares ſhould be
To Counſell deafe, but not to Flatterie.Exit

speech.speaker: Sen.
speech.line: And late ﬁue thouſand: to Varro and to Iſidore
He owes nine thouſand, beſides my former ſumme,
Which makes it ﬁue and twenty. Still in motion
Of raging waſte? It cannot hold, it will not.
If I want Gold, ſteale but a beggers Dogge,
And giue it Timon, why the Dogge coines Gold.
If I would ſell my Horſe, and buy twenty mœ
Better then he; why giue my Horſe to Timon.
Aske nothing, giue it him, it Foles me ſtraight
And able Horſes: No Porter at his gate,
But rather one that ſmiles, and ſtill inuites
All that paſſe by. It cannot hold, no reaſon
Can ſound his ſtate in ſafety. Caphis hoa,
Caphis I ſay.

speech.speaker: Ca.
speech.line: Heere ſir, what is your pleaſure.

speech.speaker: Sen.
speech.line: Get on your cloake, & haſt you to Lord Timon,
Importune him for my Moneyes, be not ceaſt
With ſlight deniall; nor then ſilenc’d, when
Commend me to your Maſter, and the Cap
Playes in the right hand, thus: but tell him,
My Vſes cry to me; I muſt ſerue my turne
Out of mine owne, his dayes and times are paſt,
And my reliances on his fraƈted dates
Haue ſmit my credit. I loue, and honour him,
But muſt not breake my backe, to heale his ﬁnger.
Immediate are my needs, and my releefe
Muſt not be toſt and turn’d to me in words,
But ﬁnde ſupply immediate. Get you gone,
Put on a moſt importunate aſpeƈt,
A viſage of demand: for I do feare
When euery Feather ſtickes in his owne wing,
Lord Timon will be leﬅ a naked gull,
Which ﬂaſhes now a Phœnix, get you gone.

speech.speaker: Ca.
speech.line: I go ſir.

speech.speaker: Sen.
speech.line: I go ſir?
Take the Bonds along with you,
And haue the dates in. Come.

speech.speaker: Ca.
speech.line: I will Sir.

speech.speaker: Sen.
speech.line: Go.Exeunt

act.stagedir: Enter Steward, with many billes in his hand.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: No care, no ſtop, ſo ſenſeleſſe of expence,
That he will neither know how to maintaine it,
Nor ceaſe his ﬂow of Riot. Takes no accompt
How things go from him, nor reſume no care
Of what is to continue: neuer minde,
Was to be ſo vnwiſe, to be ſo kinde.
What ſhall be done, he will not heare, till feele:
I muſt be round with him, now he comes from hunting.
Fye, ﬁe, ﬁe, ﬁe.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Good euen Varro: what, you come for money?

speech.speaker: Var.
speech.line: Is’t not your buſineſſe too?

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: It is, and yours too, Iſidore?

speech.speaker: Isid.
speech.line: It is ſo.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Would we were all diſcharg’d.

speech.speaker: Var.
speech.line: I feare it,

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Heere comes the Lord.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: So ſoone as dinners done, wee’l forth againe
My Alcibiades. With me, what is your will?

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: My Lord, heere is a note of certaine dues.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Dues? whence are you?

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Of Athens heere, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Go to my Steward.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Pleaſe it your Lordſhip, he hath put me off
To the ſucceſſion of new dayes this moneth:
My Maſter is awak’d by great Occaſion,
To call vpon his owne, and humbly prayes you,
That with your other Noble parts, you’l ſuite,
In giuing him his right.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Mine honeſt Friend,
I prythee but repaire to me next morning.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Nay, good my Lord.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Containe thy ſelfe, good Friend.

speech.speaker: Var.
speech.line: One Varrœs ſeruant, my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Iſid.
speech.line: From Iſidore, he humbly prayes your ſpeedy pay-
ment.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: If you did know my Lord, my Maſters wants.

speech.speaker: Var.
speech.line: ’Twas due on forfeyture my Lord, ſixe weekes,
and paſt.

speech.speaker: Iſi.
speech.line: Your Steward puts me off my Lord, and I
Am ſent expreſſely to your Lordſhip.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Giue me breath:
I do beſeech you good my Lords keepe on,
Ile waite vpon you inſtantly. Come hither: pray you
How gœs the world, that I am thus encountred
With clamorous demands of debt, broken Bonds,
And the detention of long ſince due debts
Againſt my Honor?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Pleaſe you Gentlemen,
The time is vnagreeable to this buſineſſe:
Your importunacie ceaſe, till aﬅer dinner,
That I may make his Lordſhip vnderſtand
Wherefore you are not paid.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Do ſo my Friends, ſee them well entertain’d.

speech.speaker: Stew
speech.line: Pray draw neere.Exit.

speech.speaker: Caph.
speech.line: Stay, ſtay, here comes the Foole with Apeman-
tus, let’s ha ſome ſport with ’em.

speech.speaker: Var.
speech.line: Hang him, hee’l abuſe vs.

speech.speaker: Iſid.
speech.line: A plague vpon him dogge.

speech.speaker: Var.
speech.line: How doſt Foole?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Doſt Dialogue with thy ſhadow?

speech.speaker: Var.
speech.line: I ſpeake not to thee.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: No ’tis to thy ſelfe. Come away.

speech.speaker: Iſi.
speech.line: There’s the Foole hangs on your backe already.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: No thou ſtand’ſt ſingle, th’art not on him yet.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Where’s the Foole now?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: He laſt ask’d the queſtion. Poore Rogues, and
Vſurers men, Bauds betweene Gold and want.

speech.speaker: Al.
speech.line: What are we Apemantus?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Aſſes.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Why?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: That you ask me what you are, & do not know
your ſelues. Speake to ’em Foole.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: How do you Gentlemen?

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Gramercies good Foole:
How dœs your Miſtris?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: She’s e’ne ſetting on water to ſcal’d ſuch Chic-
kens as you are. Would we could ſee you at Corinth.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Good, Gramercy.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Looke you, heere comes my Maſters Page.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: Why how now Captaine? what do you in this
wiſe Company.
How doſt thou Apermantus?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Would I had a Rod in my mouth, that I might
anſwer thee proﬁtably.

speech.speaker: Boy.
speech.line: Prythee Apemantus reade me the ſuperſcripti-
on of theſe Letters, I know not which is which.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Canſt not read?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: There will litle Learning dye then that day thou
art hang’d. This is to Lord Timon, this to Alcibiades. Go
thou was’t borne a Baſtard, and thou’t dye a Bawd.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: Thou was’t whelpt a Dogge, and thou ſhalt
famiſh a Dogges death.
Anſwer not, I am gone.Exit

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: E’ne ſo thou out-runſt Grace,
Foole I will go with you to Lord Timons.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Will you leaue me there?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: If Timon ſtay at home.
You three ſerue three Vſurers?

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: I would they ſeru’d vs.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: So would I:
As good a tricke as euer Hangman ſeru’d Theefe.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Are you three Vſurers men?

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: I Foole.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: I thinke no Vſurer, but ha’s a Foole to his Ser-
uant. My Miſtris is one, and I am her Foole: when men
come to borrow of your Maſters, they approach ſadly,
and go away merry: but they enter my Maſters houſe
merrily, and go away ſadly. The reaſon of this?

speech.speaker: Var.
speech.line: I could render one.

speech.speaker: Ap.
speech.line: Do it then, that we may account thee a Whore-
maſter, and a Knaue, which notwithſtanding thou ſhalt
be no leſſe eſteemed.

speech.speaker: Varro.
speech.line: What is a Whoremaſter Foole?

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: A Foole in good cloathes, and ſomething like
thee. ’Tis a ſpirit, ſometime t’appeares like a Lord, ſom-
time like a Lawyer, ſometime like a Philoſopher, with
two ſtones mœ then’s artiﬁciall one. Hee is verie oﬅen
like a Knight; and generally, in all ſhapes that man gœs
vp and downe in, from foureſcore to thirteen, this ſpirit
walkes in.

speech.speaker: Var.
speech.line: Thou art not altogether a Foole.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: Nor thou altogether a Wiſe man,
As much foolerie as I haue, ſo much wit thou lack’ſt.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: That anſwer might haue become Apemantus.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Aſide, aſide, heere comes Lord Timon.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Come with me (Foole) come.

speech.speaker: Foole.
speech.line: I do not alwayes follow Louer, elder Brother,
and Woman, ſometime the Philoſopher.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Pray you walke neere,
Ile ſpeake with you anon.Exeunt.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: You make me meruell wherefore ere this time
Had you not fully laide my ſtate before me,
That I might ſo haue rated my expence
As I had leaue of meanes.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: You would not heare me:
At many leyſures I propoſe.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Go too:
Perchance ſome ſingle vantages you tooke,
When my indiſpoſition put you backe,
And that vnaptneſſe made your miniſter
Thus to excuſe your ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: O my good Lord,
At many times I brought in my accompts,
Laid them before you, you would throw them off,
And ſay you ſound them in mine honeſtie,
When for ſome triﬂing preſent you haue bid me
Returne ſo much, I haue ſhooke my head, and wept:
Yea ’gainſt th’Authoritie of manners, pray’d you
To hold your hand more cloſe: I did indure
Not ſildome, nor no ſlight checkes, when I haue
Prompted you in the ebbe of your eſtate,
And your great ﬂow of debts; my lou’d Lord,
Though you heare now (too late) yet nowes a time,
The greateſt of your hauing, lackes a halfe,
To pay your preſent debts.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Let all my Land be ſold.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: ’Tis all engag’d, ſome forfeyted and gone,
And what remaines will hardly ſtop the mouth
Of preſent dues; the future comes apace:
What ſhall defend the interim, and at length
How gœs our reck’ning?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: To Lacedemon did my Land extend.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: O my good Lord, the world is but a word,
Were it all yours, to giue it in a breath,
How quickely were it gone.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: You tell me true.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: If you ſuſpeƈt my Husbandry or Falſhood,
Call me before th’exaƈteſt Auditors,
And ſet me on the proofe. So the Gods bleſſe me,
When all our Ofﬁces haue beene oppreſt
With riotous Feeders, when our Vaults haue wept
With drunken ſpilth of Wine; when euery roome
Hath blaz’d with Lights, and braid with Minſtrelſie,
I haue retyr’d me to a waſtefull cocke,
And ſet mine eyes at ﬂow.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Prythee no more.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Heauens, haue I ſaid, the bounty of this Lord:
How many prodigall bits haue Slaues and Pezants
This night englutted: who is not Timons,
What heart, head, ſword, force, meanes, but is L.Timons:
Great Timon, Noble, Worthy, Royall Timon:
Ah, when the meanes are gone, that buy this praiſe,
The breath is gone, whereof this praiſe is made:
Feaſt won, faſt loſt; one cloud of Winter ſhowres,
Theſe ﬂyes are coucht.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Come ſermon me no further.
No villanous bounty yet hath paſt my heart;
Vnwiſely, not ignobly haue I giuen.
Why doſt thou weepe, canſt thou the conſcience lacke,
To thinke I ſhall lacke friends: ſecure thy heart,
If I would broach the veſſels of my loue,
And try the argument of hearts, by borrowing,
Men, and mens fortunes could I frankely vſe
As I can bid thee ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Ste.
speech.line: Aſſurance bleſſe your thoughts.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: And in ſome ſort theſe wants of mine are crown’d,
That I account them bleſſings. For by theſe
Shall I trie Friends. You ſhall perceiue
How you miſtake my Fortunes:
I am wealthie in my Friends.
Within there, Flauius, Seruilius?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: My Lord, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I will diſpatch you ſeuerally.
You to Lord Lucius, to Lord Lucullus you, I hunted
with his Honor to day; you to Sempronius; commend me
to their loues; and I am proud ſay, that my occaſions
haue found time to vſe ’em toward a ſupply of mony: let
the requeſt be ﬁﬅy Talents.

speech.speaker: Flam.
speech.line: As you haue ſaid, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Lord Lucius and Lucullus? Humh.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Go you ſir to the Senators;
Of whom, euen to the States beſt health; I haue
Deſeru’d this Hearing: bid ’em ſend o’th inſtant
A thouſand Talents to me.

speech.speaker: Ste.
speech.line: I haue beene bold
(For that I knew it the moſt generall way)
To them, to vſe your Signet, and your Name,
But they do ſhake their heads, and I am heere
No richer in returne.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Is’t true? Can’t be?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: They anſwer in a ioynt and corporate voice,
That now they are at fall, want Treature cannot
Do what they would, are ſorrie: you are Honourable,
But yet they could haue wiſht, they know not,
Something hath beene amiſſe; a Noble Nature
May catch a wrench; would all were well; tis pitty,
And ſo intending other ſerious matters,
Aﬅer diſtaſtefull lookes; and theſe hard Fraƈtions
With certaine halfe-caps, and cold mouing nods,
They froze me into Silence.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: You Gods reward them:
Prythee man looke cheerely. Theſe old Fellowes
Haue their ingratitude in them Hereditary:
Their blood is cak’d, ’tis cold, it ſildome ﬂowes,
’Tis lacke of kindely warmth, they are not kinde;
And Nature, as it growes againe toward earth,
Is faſhion’d for the iourney, dull and heauy.
Go to Ventiddius (prythee be not ſad,
Thou art true, and honeſt; Ingeniouſly I ſpeake,
No blame belongs to thee:) Ventiddius lately
Buried his Father, by whoſe death hee’s ſtepp’d
Into a great eſtate: When he was poore,
Impriſon’d, and in ſcarſitie of Friends,
I cleer’d him with ﬁue Talents: Greet him from me,
Bid him ſuppoſe, ſome good neceſſity
Touches his Friend, which craues to be remembred
With thoſe ﬁue Talents; that had, giue’t theſe Fellowes
To whom ’tis inſtant due. Neu’r ſpeake, or thinke,
That Timons fortunes ’mong his Friends can ſinke.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I would I could not thinke it:
That thought is Bounties Fœ;
Being free it ſelfe, it thinkes all others ſo.Exeunt

act.stagedir: Flaminius waiting to ſpeake with a Lord from his Maſter, enters a ſeruant to him.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: I haue told my Lord of you, he is comming down
to you.

speech.speaker: Flam.
speech.line: I thanke you Sir.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Heere’s my Lord.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: One of Lord Timons men? A Guiﬅ I warrant.
Why this hits right: I dreampt of a Siluer Baſon & Ewre
to night. Flaminius, honeſt Flaminius, you are verie re-
ſpeƈtiuely welcome ſir. Fill me ſome Wine. And how
dœs that Honourable, Compleate, Free-hearted Gentle-
man of Athens, thy very bountifull good Lord and May-
ſter? _

speech.speaker: Flam.
speech.line: His health is well ſir.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I am right glad that his health is well ſir: and
what haſt thou there vnder thy Cloake, pretty Flaminius?

speech.speaker: Flam.
speech.line: Faith, nothing but an empty box Sir, which in
my Lords behalfe, I come to intreat your Honor to ſup-
ply: who hauing great and inſtant occaſion to vſe ﬁﬅie
Talents, hath ſent to your Lordſhip to furniſh him: no-
thing doubting your preſent aſſiſtance therein.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: La, la, la, la: Nothing doubting ſayes hee? Alas
good Lord, a Noble Gentleman ’tis, if he would not keep
ſo good a houſe. Many a time and oﬅen I ha din’d with
him, and told him on’t, and come againe to ſupper to him
of purpoſe, to haue him ſpend leſſe, and yet he wold em-
brace no counſell, take no warning by my comming, eue-
ry man has his fault, and honeſty is his. I ha told him on’t,
but I could nere get him from’t.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Pleaſe your Lordſhip, heere is the Wine.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Flaminius, I haue noted thee alwayes wiſe.
Heere’s to thee.

speech.speaker: Flam.
speech.line: Your Lordſhip ſpeakes your pleaſure.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I haue obſerued thee alwayes for a towardlie
prompt ſpirit, giue thee thy due, and one that knowes
what belongs to reaſon; and canſt vſe the time wel, if the
time vſe thee well. Good parts in thee; get you gone ſir-
rah. Draw neerer honeſt Flaminius. Thy Lords a boun-
tifull Gentleman, but thou art wiſe, and thou know’ſt
well enough (although thou com’ſt to me) that this is no
time to lend money, eſpecially vpon bare friendſhippe
without ſecuritie. Here’s three Solidares for thee, good
Boy winke at me, and ſay thou ſaw’ſt mee not. Fare thee
well.

speech.speaker: Flam.
speech.line: Is’t poſſible the world ſhould ſo much differ,
And we aliue that liued? Fly damned baſeneſſe
To him that worſhips thee.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Ha? Now I ſee thou art a Foole, and ﬁt for thy
Maſter.Exit L.

speech.speaker: Flam.
speech.line: May theſe adde to the number ý may ſcald thee:
Let moulten Coine be thy damnation,
Thou diſeaſe of a friend, and not himſelfe:
Has friendſhip ſuch a faint and milkie heart,
It turnes in leſſe then two nights? O you Gods!
I feele my Maſters paſſion. This Slaue vnto his Honor,
Has my Lords meate in him:
Why ſhould it thriue, and turne to Nutriment,
When he is turn’d to poyſon?
O may Diſeaſes onely worke vpon’t:
And when he’s ſicke to death, let not that part of Nature
Which my Lord payd for, be of any power
To expell ſickneſſe, but prolong his hower.Exit.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Who the Lord Timon? He is my very good friend
and an Honourable Gentleman.
We know him for no leſſe, thogh we are but ſtran-
gers to him. But I can tell you one thing my Lord, and
which I heare from common rumours, now Lord Timons
happie howres are done and paſt, and his eſtate ſhrinkes
from him.

speech.speaker: Lucius.
speech.line: Fye no, dœ not beleeue it: hee cannot want
for money.
But beleeue you this my Lord, that not long agœ,
one of his men was with the Lord Lucullus, to borrow ſo
many Talents, nay vrg’d extreamly for’t, and ſhewed
what neceſſity belong’d too’t, and yet was deny’de.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: How?
I tell you, deny’de my Lord.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: What a ſtrange caſe was that? Now before the
Gods I am aſham’d on’t. Denied that honourable man?
There was verie little Honour ſhew’d in’t. For my owne
part, I muſt needes confeſſe, I haue receyued ſome ſmall
kindneſſes from him, as Money, Plate, Iewels, and ſuch
like Triﬂes; nothing comparing to his: yet had hee mi-
ſtooke him, and ſent to me, I ſhould ne’re haue denied his
Occaſion ſo many Talents.

speech.speaker: Seruil.
speech.line: See, by good hap yonders my Lord, I haue
ſwet to ſee his Honor. My Honor’d Lord.

speech.speaker: Lucil.
speech.line: Seruilius? You are kindely met ſir. Farthewell,
commend me to thy Honourable vertuous Lord, my ve-
ry exquiſite Friend.

speech.speaker: Seruil.
speech.line: May it pleaſe your Honour, my Lord hath
ſent—

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Ha? what ha’s he ſent? I am ſo much endeered
to that Lord; hee’s euer ſending: how ſhall I thank him
think’ſt thou? And what has he ſent now?

speech.speaker: Seruil.
speech.line: Has onely ſent his preſent Occaſion now my
Lord: requeſting your Lordſhip to ſupply his inſtant vſe
with ſo many Talents.

speech.speaker: Lucil.
speech.line: I know his Lordſhip is but merry with me,
He cannot want ﬁﬅy ﬁue hundred Talents.

speech.speaker: Seruil.
speech.line: But in the mean time he wants leſſe my Lord.
If his occaſion were not vertuous,
I ſhould not vrge it halfe ſo faithfully.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Doſt thou ſpeake ſeriouſly Seruilius?

speech.speaker: Seruil.
speech.line: Vpon my ſoule ’tis true Sir.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: What a wicked Beaſt was I to diſfurniſh my
ſelf againſt ſuch a good time, when I might ha ſhewn my
ſelfe Honourable? How vnluckily it hapned, that I ſhold
Purchaſe the day before for a little part, and vndo a great
deale of Honour? Seruilius, now before the Gods I am
not able to do (the more beaſt I ſay) I was ſending to vſe
Lord Timon my ſelfe, theſe Gentlemen can witneſſe; but
I would not for the wealth of Athens I had done’t now.
Commend me bountifully to his good Lordſhip, and I
hope his Honor will conceiue the faireſt of mee, becauſe
I haue no power to be kinde. And tell him this from me,
I count it one of my greateſt afﬂiƈtions ſay, that I cannot
pleaſure ſuch an Honourable Gentleman. Good Seruili-
us, will you befriend mee ſo farre, as to vſe mine owne
words to him?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Yes ſir, I ſhall.Exit Seruil.

speech.speaker: Lucil.
speech.line: Ile looke you out a good turne Seruilius.
True as you ſaid, Timon is ſhrunke indeede,
And he that’s once deny’de, will hardly ſpeede.Exit.
Do you obſerue this Hoſtilius?
I, to well.
Why this is the worlds ſoule,
And iuſt of the ſame peece
Is euery Flatterers ſport: who can call him his Friend
That dips in the ſame diſh? For in my knowing
Timon has bin this Lords Father,
And kept his credit with his purſe:
Supported his eſtate, nay Timons money
Has paid his men their wages. He ne’re drinkes,
But Timons Siluer treads vpon his Lip,
And yet, oh ſee the monſtrouſneſſe of man,
When he lookes out in an vngratefull ſhape;
He dœs deny him (in reſpeƈt of his)
What charitable men affoord to Beggers.
Religion grones at it.
For mine owne part, I neuer taſted Timon in my life
Nor came any of his bounties ouer me,
To marke me for his Friend. Yet I proteſt,
For his right Noble minde, illuſtrious Vertue,
And Honourable Carriage,
Had his neceſſity made vſe of me,
I would haue put my wealth into Donation,
And the beſt halfe ſhould haue return’d to him,
So much I loue his heart: But I perceiue,
Men muſt learne now with pitty to diſpence,
For Policy ſits aboue Conſcience.Exeunt.

act.stagedir: Enter a third ſeruant with Sempronius, another of Timons Friends.

speech.speaker: Semp.
speech.line: Muſt he needs trouble me in’t? Hum.
’Boue all others?
He might haue tried Lord Lucius, or Lucullus,
And now Ventidgius is wealthy too,
Whom he redeem’d from priſon. All theſe
Owes their eſtates vnto him.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: My Lord,
They haue all bin touch’d, and found Baſe-Mettle,
For they haue all denied him.

speech.speaker: Semp.
speech.line: How? Haue they deny’de him?
Has Ventidgius and Lucullus deny’de him,
And dœs he ſend to me? Three? Humh?
It ſhewes but little loue, or iudgement in him.
Muſt I be his laſt Refuge? His Friends (like Phyſitians)
Thriue, giue him ouer: Muſt I take th’ Cure vpon me?
Has much diſgrac’d me in’t, I’me angry at him,
That might haue knowne my place. I ſee no ſenſe for’t,
But his Occaſions might haue woœd me ﬁrſt:
For in my conſcience, I was the ﬁrſt man
That ere receiued guiﬅ from him.
And dœs he thinke ſo backwardly of me now,
That Ile requite it laſt? No:
So it may proue an Argument of Laughter
To th’ reſt, and ’mong’ſt Lords be thought a Foole:
I’de rather then the worth of thrice the ſumme,
Had ſent to me ﬁrſt, but for my mindes ſake:
I’de ſuch a courage to do him good. But now returne,
And with their faint reply, this anſwer ioyne;
Who bates mine Honor, ſhall not know my Coyne.Exit

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Excellent: Your Lordſhips a goodly Villain: the
diuell knew not what he did, when hee made man Poli-
ticke; he croſſed himſelfe by’t: and I cannot thinke, but
in the end, the Villanies of man will ſet him cleere. How
fairely this Lord ſtriues to appeare foule? Takes Vertu-
ous Copies to be wicked: like thoſe, that vnder hotte ar-
dent zeale, would ſet whole Realmes on ﬁre, of ſuch a na-
ture is his politike loue.
This was my Lords beſt hope, now all are ﬂed
Saue onely the Gods. Now his Friends are dead,
Doores that were ne’re acquainted with their Wards
Many a bounteous yeere, muſt be imploy’d
Now to guard ſure their Maſter:
And this is all a liberall courſe allowes,
Who cannot keepe his wealth, muſt keep his houſe. Exit.

act.stagedir: Enter Varro’s man, meeting others. All Timons Creditors to wait for his comming out. Then enter Lucius and Hortenſius.

speech.speaker: Var.man.
speech.line: Well met, goodmorrow Titus & Hortenſius

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: The like to you kinde Varro.

speech.speaker: Hort.
speech.line: Lucius, what do we meet together?

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: I, and I think one buſineſſe do’s command vs all.
For mine is money.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: So is theirs, and ours.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: And ſir Philotus too.

speech.speaker: Phil.
speech.line: Good day at once.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Welcome good Brother.
What do you thinke the houre?

speech.speaker: Phil.
speech.line: Labouring for Nine.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: So much?

speech.speaker: Phil.
speech.line: Is not my Lord ſeene yet?

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Not yet.

speech.speaker: Phil.
speech.line: I wonder on’t, he was wont to ſhine at ſeauen.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: I, but the dayes are waxt ſhorter with him:
You muſt conſider, that a Prodigall courſe
Is like the Sunnes, but not like his recouerable, I feare:
’Tis deepeſt Winter in Lord Timons purſe, that is: One
may reach deepe enough, and yet ﬁnde little.

speech.speaker: Phil.
speech.line: I am of your feare, for that.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Ile ſhew you how t’obſerue a ſtrange euent:
Your Lord ſends now for Money?

speech.speaker: Hort.
speech.line: Moſt true, he dœ’s.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: And he weares Iewels now of Timons guiﬅ,
For which I waite for money.

speech.speaker: Hort.
speech.line: It is againſt my heart.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Marke how ſtrange it ſhowes,
Timon in this, ſhould pay more then he owes:
And e’ne as if your Lord ſhould weare rich Iewels,
And ſend for money for ’em.

speech.speaker: Hort.
speech.line: I’me weary of this Charge,
The Gods can witneſſe:
I know my Lord hath ſpent of Timons wealth,
And now Ingratitude, makes it worſe then ſtealth.

speech.speaker: Varro.
speech.line: Yes, mine’s three thouſand Crownes:
What’s yours?

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Fiue thouſand mine.

speech.speaker: Varro.
speech.line: ’Tis much deepe, and it ſhould ſeem by th’ſum
Your Maſters conﬁdence was aboue mine,
Elſe ſurely his had equall’d.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: One of Lord Timons men.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Flaminius? Sir, a word: Pray is my Lord readie
to come forth?

speech.speaker: Flam.
speech.line: No, indeed he is not.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: We attend his Lordſhip: pray ſigniﬁe ſo much.

speech.speaker: Flam.
speech.line: I need not tell him that, he knowes you are too diligent.

act.stagedir: Enter Steward in a Cloake, mufﬂed.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Ha: is not that his Steward mufﬂed ſo?
He gœs away in a Clowd: Call him, call him.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Do you heare, ſir?

speech.speaker: 2.Varro.
speech.line: By your leaue, ſir.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: What do ye aske of me, my Friend.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: We waite for certaine Money heere, ſir.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I, if Money were as certaine as your waiting,
’Twere ſure enough.
Why then preferr’d you not your ſummes and Billes
When your falſe Maſters eate of my Lords meat?
Then they could ſmile, and fawne vpon his debts.
And take downe th’Intreſt into their glutt’nous Mawes.
You do your ſelues but wrong, to ſtirre me vp,
Let me paſſe quietly:
Beleeue’t, my Lord and I haue made an end,
I haue no more to reckon, he to ſpend.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: I, but this anſwer will not ſerue.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: If’t ’twill not ſerue, ’tis not ſo baſe as you,
For you ſerue Knaues.

speech.speaker: 1.Varro.
speech.line: How? What dœs his caſheer’d Worſhip
mutter?

speech.speaker: 2.Varro.
speech.line: No matter what, hee’s poore, and that’s re-
uenge enough. Who can ſpeake broader, then hee that
has no houſe to put his head in? Such may rayle againſt
great buildings.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Oh heere’s Seruilius: now wee ſhall know ſome
anſwere.

speech.speaker: Seru.
speech.line: If I might beſeech you Gentlemen, to repayre
ſome other houre, I ſhould deriue much from’t. For tak’t
of my ſoule, my Lord leanes wondrouſly to diſcontent:
His comfortable temper has forſooke him, he’s much out
of health, and keepes his Chamber.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Many do keepe their Chambers, are not ſicke:
And if it be ſo farre beyond his health,
Me thinkes he ſhould the ſooner pay his debts,
And make a cleere way to the Gods.

speech.speaker: Seruil.
speech.line: Good Gods.

speech.speaker: Titus.
speech.line: We cannot take this for anſwer, ſir.
Flaminius within.Seruilius helpe, my Lord, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: What, are my dores oppos’d againſt my paſſage?
Haue I bin euer free, and muſt my houſe
Be my retentiue Enemy? My Gaole?
The place which I haue Feaſted, dœs it now
(Like all Mankinde) ſhew me an Iron heart?

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Put in now Titus.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: My Lord, heere is my Bill.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Here’s mine.

speech.speaker: 1.Var.
speech.line: And mine, my Lord.

speech.speaker: 2.Var.
speech.line: And ours, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Philo.
speech.line: All our Billes.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Knocke me downe with ’em, cleaue mee to the
Girdle.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Alas, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Cut my heart in ſummes.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Mine, ﬁﬅy Talents.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Tell out my blood.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Fiue thouſand Crownes, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Fiue thouſand drops payes that.
What yours? and yours?

speech.speaker: 1.Var.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: 2.Var.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Teare me, take me, and the Gods fall vpon you.

speech.speaker: Hort.
speech.line: Faith I perceiue our Maſters may throwe their
caps at their money, theſe debts may well be call’d deſpe-
rate ones, for a madman owes ’em.Exeunt.

speech.speaker: Timon.
speech.line: They haue e’ene put my breath from mee the
ſlaues. Creditors? Diuels.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: My deere Lord.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: What if it ſhould be ſo?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Ile haue it ſo. My Steward?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Heere my Lord.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: So ﬁtly? Go, bid all my Friends againe,
Lucius, Lucullus, and Sempronius Vllorxa: All,
Ile once more feaſt the Raſcals.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: O my Lord, you onely ſpeake from your diſtra-
ƈted ſoule; there’s not ſo much leﬅ to furniſh out a mo-
derate Table.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Be it not in thy care:
Go I charge thee, inuite them all, let in the tide
Of Knaues once more: my Cooke and Ile prouide.Exeunt

act.stagedir: Enter three Senators at one doore, Alcibiades meeting them, with Attendants.

speech.speaker: 1.Sen.
speech.line: My Lord, you haue my voyce, too’t,
The faults Bloody:
’Tis neceſſary he ſhould dye:
Nothing imboldens ſinne ſo much, as Mercy.
Moſt true; the Law ſhall bruiſe ’em.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: Honor, health, and compaſſion to the Senate.
Now Captaine.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: I am an humble Sutor to your Vertues;
For pitty is the vertue of the Law,
And none but Tyrants vſe it cruelly.
It pleaſes time and Fortune to lye heauie
Vpon a Friend of mine, who in hot blood
Hath ſtept into the Law: which is paſt depth
To thoſe that (without heede) do plundge intoo’t.
He is a Man (ſetting his Fate aſide) of comely Vertues,
Nor did he ſoyle the faƈt with Cowardice.
(And Honour in him, which buyes out his fault)
But with a Noble Fury, and faire ſpirit,
Seeing his Reputation touch’d to death,
He did oppoſe his Fœ:
And with ſuch ſober and vnnoted paſſion
He did behooue his anger ere ’twas ſpent,
As if he had but prou’d an Argument.

speech.speaker: 1.Sen.
speech.line: You vndergo too ſtriƈt a Paradox,
Striuing to make an vgly deed looke faire:
Your words haue tooke ſuch paines, as if they labour’d
To bring Man-ſlaughter into forme, and ſet Quarrelling
Vpon the head of Valour; which indeede
Is Valour miſ-begot, and came into the world,
When Seƈts, and Faƈtions were newly borne.
Hee’s truly Valiant, that can wiſely ſuffer
The worſt that man can breath,
And make his Wrongs, his Out-ſides,
To weare them like his Rayment, careleſſely,
And ne’re preferre his iniuries to his heart,
To bring it into danger.
If Wrongs be euilles, and inforce vs kill,
What Folly ’tis, to hazard life for Ill.

speech.speaker: Alci.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: 1.Sen.
speech.line: You cannot make groſſe ſinnes looke cleare,
To reuenge is no Valour, but to beare.

speech.speaker: Alci.
speech.line: My Lords, then vnder fauour, pardon me,
If I ſpeake like a Captaine.
Why do fond men expoſe themſelues to Battell,
And not endure all threats? Sleepe vpon’t,
And let the Fœs quietly cut their Throats
Without repugnancy? If there be
Such Valour in the bearing, what make wee
Abroad? Why then, Women are more valiant
That ſtay at home, if Bearing carry it:
And the Aſſe, more Captaine then the Lyon?
The fellow loaden with Irons, wiſer then the Iudge?
If Wiſedome be in ſuffering. Oh my Lords,
As you are great, be pittifully Good,
Who cannot condemne raſhneſſe in cold blood?
To kill, I grant, is ſinnes extreameſt Guſt,
But in defence, by Mercy, ’tis moſt iuſt.
To be in Anger, is impietie:
But who is Man, that is not Angrie.
Weigh but the Crime with this.

speech.speaker: 2.Sen.
speech.line: You breath in vaine.

speech.speaker: Alci.
speech.line: In vaine?
His ſeruice done at Lacedemon, and Bizantium,
Were a ſufﬁcient briber for his life.
What’s that?

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: Why ſay my Lords ha’s done faire ſeruice,
And ſlaine in ﬁght many of your enemies:
How full of valour did he beare himſelfe
In the laſt Conﬂiƈt, and made plenteous wounds?
He has made too much plenty with him:
He’s a ſworne Riotor, he has a ſinne
That oﬅen drownes him, and takes his valour priſoner.
If there were no Fœs, that were enough
To ouercome him. In that Beaſtly furie,
He has bin knowne to commit outrages,
And cherriſh Faƈtions. ’Tis inferr’d to vs,
His dayes are foule, and his drinke dangerous.
He dyes.

speech.speaker: Alci.
speech.line: Hard fate: he might haue dyed in warre.
My Lords, if not for any parts in him,
Though his right arme might purchaſe his owne time,
And be in debt to none: yet more to moue you,
Take my deſerts to his, and ioyne ’em both.
And for I know, your reuerend Ages loue Security,
Ile pawne my Viƈtories, all my Honour to you
Vpon his good returnes.
If by this Crime, he owes the Law his life,
Why let the Warre receiue’t in valiant gore,
For Law is ſtriƈt, and Warre is nothing more.
We are for Law, he dyes, vrge it no more
On height of our diſpleaſure: Friend, or Brother,
He forfeits his owne blood, that ſpilles another.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: Muſt it be ſo? It muſt not bee:
My Lords, I do beſeech you know mee.
How?

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: Call me to your remembrances.
What.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: I cannot thinke but your Age has forgot me,
It could not elſe be, I ſhould proue ſo bace,
To ſue and be deny’de ſuch common Grace.
My wounds ake at you.
Do you dare our anger?
’Tis in few words, but ſpacious in effeƈt:
We baniſh thee for euer.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: Baniſh me?
Baniſh your dotage, baniſh vſurie,
That makes the Senate vgly.
If aﬅer two dayes ſhine, Athens containe thee,
Attend our waightier Iudgement.
And not to ſwell our Spirit,
He ſhall be executed preſently.Exeunt.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: Now the Gods keepe you old enough,
That you may liue
Onely in bone, that none may looke on you.
I’m worſe then mad: I haue kept backe their Fœs
While they haue told their Money, and let out
Their Coine vpon large intereſt. I my ſelfe,
Rich onely in large hurts. All thoſe, for this?
Is this the Balſome, that the vſuring Senat
Powres into Captaines wounds? Baniſhment.
It comes not ill: I hate not to be baniſht,
It is a cauſe worthy my Spleene and Furie,
That I may ſtrike at Athens. Ile cheere vp
My diſcontented Troopes, and lay for hearts;
’Tis Honour with moſt Lands to be at ods,
Souldiers ſhould brooke as little wrongs as Gods.Exit.

act.stagedir: Enter diuers Friends at ſeuerall doores.

speech.line: The good time of day to you, ſir.
I alſo wiſh it to you: I thinke this Honorable Lord
did but try vs this other day.
Vpon that were my thoughts tyring when wee en-
countred. I hope it is not ſo low with him as he made it
ſeeme in the triall of his ſeuerall Friends.
It ſhould not be, by the perſwaſion of his new Fea-
ſting.
I ſhould thinke ſo. He hath ſent mee an earneſt in-
uiting, which many my neere occaſions did vrge mee to
put off: but he hath coniur’d mee beyond them, and I
muſt needs appeare.
In like manner was I in debt to my importunat bu-
ſineſſe, but he would not heare my excuſe. I am ſorrie,
when he ſent to borrow of mee, that my Prouiſion was
out.
I am ſicke of that greefe too, as I vnderſtand how all
things go.
Euery man heares ſo: what would hee haue borro-
wed of you?
A thouſand Peeces.
A thouſand Peeces?
What of you?
He ſent to me ſir— Heere he comes.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: With all my heart Gentlemen both; and how
fare you?
Euer at the beſt, hearing well of your Lordſhip.
The Swallow followes not Summer more willing,
then we your Lordſhip.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Nor more willingly leaues Winter, ſuch Sum-
mer Birds are men. Gentlemen, our dinner will not re-
compence this long ſtay: Feaſt your eares with the Mu-
ſicke awhile: If they will fare ſo harſhly o’th’ Trumpets
ſound: we ſhall too’t preſently.
I hope it remaines not vnkindely with your Lord-
ſhip, that I return’d you an empty Meſſenger.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: O ſir, let it not trouble you.
My Noble Lord.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Ah my good Friend, what cheere?
My moſt Honorable Lord, I am e’ne ſick of ſhame,
that when your Lordſhip this other day ſent to me, I was
ſo vnfortunate a Beggar.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Thinke not on’t, ſir.
If you had ſent but two houres before.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Let it not cumber your better remembrance.
Come bring in all together.
All couer’d Diſhes.
Royall Cheare, I warrant you.
Doubt not that, if money and the ſeaſon can yeild it
How do you? What’s the newes?
Alcibiades is baniſh’d: heare you of it?

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: Alcibiades baniſh’d?
’Tis ſo, be ſure of it.
How? How?
I pray you vpon what?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: My worthy Friends, will you draw neere?
Ile tell you more anon. Here’s a Noble feaſt toward
This is the old man ſtill.
Wilt hold? Wilt hold?
It do’s: but time will, and ſo.
I do conceyue.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Each man to his ſtoole, with that ſpurre as hee
would to the lip of his Miſtris: your dyet ſhall bee in all
places alike. Make not a Citie Feaſt of it, to let the meat
coole, ere we can agree vpon the ﬁrſt place. Sit, ſit.
The Gods require our Thankes.

line.italic: You great Benefaƈtors, ſprinkle our Society with Thanke-
fulneſſe. For your owne guiﬅs, make your ſelues prais’d: But
reſerue ſtill to giue, leaſt your Deities be deſpiſed. Lend to each
man enough, that one neede not lend to another. For were your
Godheads to borrow of men, men would forſake the Gods. Make
the Meate be beloued, more then the Man that giues it. Let
no Aſſembly of Twenty, be without a ſcore of Villaines. If there
ſit twelue Women at the Table, let a dozen of them bee as they
are. The reſt of your Fees, O Gods, the Senators of Athens,
together with the common legge of People, what is amiſſe in
them, you Gods, make ſuteable for deſtruƈtion. For theſe my
preſent Friends, as they are to mee nothing, ſo in nothing bleſſe
them, and to nothing are they welcome.

speech.line: Vncouer Dogges, and lap.

speech.speaker: Some ſpeake.
speech.line: What do’s his Lordſhip meane?

speech.speaker: Some other.
speech.line: I know not.

speech.speaker: Timon.
speech.line: May you a better Feaſt neuer behold
You knot of Mouth-Friends: Smoke, & lukewarm water
Is your perfeƈtion. This is Timons laſt,
Who ſtucke and ſpangled you with Flatteries,
Waſhes it off and ſprinkles in your faces
Your reeking villany. Liue loath’d, and long
Moſt ſmiling, ſmooth, deteſted Paraſites,
Curteous Deſtroyers, affable Wolues, meeke Beares:
You Fooles of Fortune, Trencher-friends, Times Flyes,
Cap and knee-Slaues, vapours, and Minute Iackes.
Of Man and Beaſt, the inﬁnite Maladie
Cruſt you quite o’re. What do’ſt thou go?
Soﬅ, take thy Phyſicke ﬁrſt; thou too, and thou:
Stay I will lend thee money, borrow none.
What? All in Motion? Henceforth be no Feaſt,
Whereat a Villaine’s not a welcome Gueſt.
Burne houſe, ſinke Athens, henceforth hated be
Of Timon Man, and all Humanity.Exit.

act.stagedir: Enter the Senators, with other Lords.

speech.line: How now, my Lords?
Know you the quality of Lord Timons fury?
Puſh, did you ſee my Cap?
I haue loſt my Gowne.
He’s but a mad Lord, & nought but humors ſwaies
him. He gaue me a Iewell th’other day, and now hee has
beate it out of my hat.
Did you ſee my Iewell?
Did you ſee my Cap.
Heere ’tis.
Heere lyes my Gowne.
Let’s make no ſtay.
Lord Timons mad.
I feel’t vpon my bones.
One day he giues vs Diamonds, next day ſtones.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Let me looke backe vpon thee. O thou Wall
That girdles in thoſe Wolues, diue in the earth,
And fence not Athens. Matrons, turne incontinent,
Obedience fayle in Children: Slaues and Fooles
Plucke the graue wrinkled Senate from the Bench,
And miniſter in their ſteeds, to generall Filthes.
Conuert o’th’ Inſtant greene Virginity,
Doo’t in your Parents eyes. Bankrupts, hold faſt
Rather then render backe; out with your Kniues,
And cut your Truſters throates. Bound Seruants, ſteale,
Large-handed Robbers your graue Maſters are,
And pill by Law. Maide, to thy Maſters bed,
Thy Miſtris is o’th’ Brothell. Some of ſixteen,
Plucke the lyn’d Crutch from thy old limping Sire,
With it, beate out his Braines. Piety, and Feare,
Religion to the Gods, Peace, Iuſtice, Truth,
Domeſticke awe, Night-reſt, and Neighbour-hood,
Inſtruƈtion, Manners, Myſteries, and Trades,
Degrees, Obſeruances, Cuſtomes, and Lawes,
Decline to your confounding contraries.
And yet Confuſion liue: Plagues incident to men,
Your potent and infeƈtious Feauors, heape
On Athens ripe for ſtroke. Thou cold Sciatica,
Cripple our Senators, that their limbes may halt
As lamely as their Manners. Luſt, and Libertie
Creepe in the Mindes and Marrowes of our youth,
That ’gainſt the ſtreame of Vertue they may ſtriue,
And drowne themſelues in Riot. Itches, Blaines,
So we all th’ Athenian boſomes, and their crop
Be generall Leproſie: Breath, infeƈt breath,
That their Society (as their Friendſhip) may
Be meerely poyſon. Nothing Ile beare from thee
But nakedneſſe, thou deteſtable Towne,
Take thou that too, with multiplying Bannes:
Timon will to the Woods, where he ſhall ﬁnde
Th’ vnkindeſt Beaſt, more kinder then Mankinde.
The Gods confound (heare me you good Gods all)
Th’ Athenians both within and out that Wall:
And graunt as Timon growes, his hate may grow
To the whole race of Mankinde, high and low.
Amen.Exit.

act.stagedir: Enter Steward with two or three Seruants.

speech.line: Heare you M. Steward, where’s our Maſter?
Are we vndone, caſt off, nothing remaining?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Alack my Fellowes, what ſhould I ſay to you?
Let me be recorded by the righteous Gods,
I am as poore as you.
Such a Houſe broke?
So Noble a Maſter falne, all gone, and not
One Friend to take his Fortune by the arme,
And go along with him.
As we do turne our backes
From our Companion, throwne into his graue,
So his Familiars to his buried Fortunes
Slinke all away, leaue their falſe vowes with him
Like empty purſes pickt; and his poore ſelfe
A dedicated Beggar to the Ayre,
With his diſeaſe, of all ſhunn’d pouerty,
Walkes like contempt alone. More of our Fellowes.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: All broken Implements of a ruin’d houſe.
Yet do our hearts weare Timons Liuery,
That ſee I by our Faces: we are Fellowes ſtill,
Seruing alike in ſorrow: Leak’d is our Barke,
And we poore Mates, ſtand on the dying Decke,
Hearing the Surges threat: we muſt all part
Into this Sea of Ayre.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Good Fellowes all,
The lateſt of my wealth Ile ſhare among’ſt you.
Where euer we ſhall meete, for Timons ſake,
Let’s yet be Fellowes. Let’s ſhake our heads, and ſay
As ’twere a Knell vnto our Maſters Fortunes,
We haue ſeene better dayes. Let each take ſome:
Nay put out all your hands: Not one word more,
Thus part we rich in ſorrow, parting poore.
Oh the ﬁerce wretchedneſſe that Glory brings vs!
Who would not wiſh to be from wealth exempt,
Since Riches point to Miſery and Contempt?
Who would be ſo mock’d with Glory, or to liue
But in a Dreame of Friendſhip,
To haue his pompe, and all what ſtate compounds,
But onely painted like his varniſht Friends:
Poore honeſt Lord, brought lowe by his owne heart,
Vndone by Goodneſſe: Strange vnvſuall blood,
When mans worſt ſinne is, He do’s too much Good.
Who then dares to be halfe ſo kinde agen?
For Bounty that makes Gods, do ſtill marre Men.
My deereſt Lord, bleſt to be moſt accurſt,
Rich onely to be wretched; thy great Fortunes
Are made thy cheefe Afﬂiƈtions. Alas (kinde Lord)
Hee’s ﬂung in Rage from this ingratefull Seate
Of monſtrous Friends:
Nor ha’s he with him to ſupply his life,
Or that which can command it:
Ile follow and enquire him out.
Ile euer ſerue his minde, with my beſt will,
Whilſt I haue Gold, Ile be his Steward ſtill.Exit.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: O bleſſed breeding Sun, draw from the earth
Rotten humidity: below thy Siſters Orbe
Infeƈt the ayre. Twin’d Brothers of one wombe,
Whoſe procreation, reſidence, and birth,
Scarſe is diuidant; touch them with ſeuerall fortunes,
The greater ſcornes the leſſer. Not Nature
(To whom all ſores lay ſiege) can beare great Fortune
But by contempt of Nature.
Raiſe me this Begger, and deny’t that Lord,
The Senators ſhall beare contempt Hereditary,
The Begger Natiue Honor.
It is the Paſtour Lards, the Brothers ſides,
The want that makes him leaue: who dares? who dares
In puritie of Manhood ſtand vpright
And ſay, this mans a Flatterer. If one be,
So are they all: for euerie grize of Fortune
Is ſmooth’d by that below. The Learned pate
Duckes to the Golden Foole. All’s obliquie:
There’s nothing leuell in our curſed Natures
But direƈt villanie. Therefore be abhorr’d,
All Feaſts, Societies, and Throngs of men.
His ſemblable, yea himſelfe Timon diſdaines,
Deſtruƈtion phang mankinde; Earth yeeld me Rootes,
Who ſeekes for better of thee, ſawce his pallate
With thy moſt operant Poyſon. What is heere?
Gold? Yellow, glittering, precious Gold?
No Gods, I am no idle Votariſt,
Roots you cleere Heauens. Thus much of this will make
Blacke, white; fowle, faire; wrong, right;
Baſe, Noble; Old, young; Coward, valiant.
Ha you Gods! why this? what this, you Gods? why this
Will lugge your Prieſts and Seruants from your ſides:
Plucke ſtout mens pillowes from below their heads.
This yellow Slaue,
Will knit and breake Religions, bleſſe th’ accurſt,
Make the hoare Leproſie ador’d, place Theeues,
And giue them Title, knee, and approbation
With Senators on the Bench: This is it
That makes the wappen’d Widdow wed againe;
Shee, whom the Spittle-houſe, and vlcerous ſores,
Would caſt the gorge at. This Embalmes and Spices
To’th’ Aprill day againe. Come damn’d Earth,
Thou common whore of Mankinde, that puttes oddes
Among the rout of Nations, I will make thee
Do thy right Nature. March afarre off.
Ha? A Drumme? Th’art quicke,
But yet Ile bury thee: Thou’t go (ſtrong Theefe)
When Gowty keepers of thee cannot ſtand:
Nay ſtay thou out for earneſt.

act.stagedir: Enter Alcibiades with Drumme and Fife in warlike manner, and Phrynia and Timandra.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: What art thou there? ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: A Beaſt as thou art. The Canker gnaw thy hart
For ſhewing me againe the eyes of Man.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: What is thy name? Is man ſo hatefull to thee,
That art thy ſelfe a Man?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I am Miſantropos, and hate Mankinde.
For thy part, I do wiſh thou wert a dogge,
That I might loue thee ſomething.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: I know thee well:
But in thy Fortunes am vnlearn’d, and ſtrange.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I know thee too, and more then that I know thee
I not deſire to know. Follow thy Drumme,
With mans blood paint the ground Gules, Gules:
Religious Cannons, ciuill Lawes are cruell,
Then what ſhould warre be? This fell whore of thine,
