Hath in her more deſtruƈtion then thy Sword,
For all her Cherubin looke.

speech.speaker: Phrin.
speech.line: Thy lips rot off.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I will not kiſſe thee, then the rot returnes
To thine owne lippes againe.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: How came the Noble Timon to this change?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: As the Moone do’s, by wanting light to giue:
But then renew I could not like the Moone,
There were no Sunnes to borrow of.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: Noble Timon, what friendſhip may I do thee?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: None, but to maintaine my opinion.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: What is it Timon?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Promiſe me Friendſhip, but performe none.
If thou wilt not promiſe, the Gods plague thee, for thou
art a man: if thou do’st performe, confound thee, for
thou art a man.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: I haue heard in ſome ſort of thy Miſeries.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Thou ſaw’ſt them when I had proſperitie.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: I ſee them now, then was a bleſſed time.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: As thine is now, held with a brace of Harlots.

speech.speaker: Timan.
speech.line: Is this th’ Athenian Minion, whom the world
Voic’d ſo regardfully?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Art thou Timandra?

speech.speaker: Timan.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Be a whore ſtill, they loue thee not that vſe thee,
giue them diſeaſes, leauing with thee their Luſt. Make
vſe of thy ſalt houres, ſeaſon the ſlaues for Tubbes and
Bathes, bring downe Roſe-cheekt youth to the Fubfaſt,
and the Diet.

speech.speaker: Timan.
speech.line: Hang thee Monſter.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: Pardon him ſweet Timandra, for his wits
Are drown’d and loſt in his Calamities.
I haue but little Gold of late, braue Timon,
The want whereof, doth dayly make reuolt
In my penurious Band. I haue heard and greeu’d
How curſed Athens, mindeleſſe of thy worth,
Forgetting thy great deeds, when Neighbour ſtates
But for thy Sword and Fortune trod vpon them.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I prythee beate thy Drum, and get thee gone.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: I am thy Friend, and pitty thee deere Timon.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: How dœſt thou pitty him whom ӳ doſt troble,
I had rather be alone.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: Why fare thee well:
Heere is ſome Gold for thee.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Keepe it, I cannot eate it.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: When I haue laid proud Athens on a heape.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Warr’st thou ’gainſt Athens.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: I Timon, and haue cauſe.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: The Gods confound them all in thy Conqueſt,
And thee aﬅer, when thou haſt Conquer’d.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: Why me, Timon?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: That by killing of Villaines
Thou was’t borne to conquer my Country.
Put vp thy Gold. Go on, heeres Gold, go on;
Be as a Plannetary plague, when Ioue
Will o’re ſome high-Vic’d City, hang his poyſon
In the ſicke ayre: let not thy ſword skip one:
Pitty not honour’d Age for his white Beard,
He is an Vſurer. Strike me the counterfet Matron,
It is her habite onely, that is honeſt,
Her ſelfe’s a Bawd. Let not the Virgins cheeke
Make ſoﬅ thy trenchant Sword: for thoſe Milke pappes
That through the window Barne bore at mens eyes,
Are not within the Leafe of pitty writ,
But ſet them down horrible Traitors. Spare not the Babe
Whoſe dimpled ſmiles from Fooles exhauſt their mercy;
Thinke it a Baſtard, whom the Oracle
Hath doubtfully pronounced, the throat ſhall cut,
And mince it ſans remorſe. Sweare againſt Obieƈts,
Put Armour on thine eares, and on thine eyes,
Whoſe proofe, nor yels of Mothers, Maides, nor Babes,
Nor ſight of Prieſts in holy Veſtments bleeding,
Shall pierce a iot. There’s Gold to pay thy Souldiers,
Make large confuſion: and thy fury ſpent,
Confounded be thy ſelfe. Speake not, be gone.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: Haſt thou Gold yet, Ile take the Gold thou gi-
ueſt me, not all thy Counſell.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Doſt thou or doſt thou not, Heauens curſe vpon
thee.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: Giue vs ſome Gold good Timon, haſt ӳ more?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Enough to make a Whore forſweare her Trade,
And to make Whores, a Bawd. Hold vp you Sluts
Your Aprons mountant; you are not Othable,
Although I know you’l ſweare, terribly ſweare
Into ſtrong ſhudders, and to heauenly Agues
Th’ immortall Gods that heare you. Spare your Oathes:
Ile truſt to your Conditions, be whores ſtill.
And he whoſe pious breath ſeekes to conuert you,
Be ſtrong in Whore, allure him, burne him vp,
Let your cloſe re predominate his ſmoke,
And be no turne-coats: yet may your paines ſix months
Be quite contrary, And Thatch
Your poore thin Roofes with burthens of the dead,
(Some that were hang’d) no matter:
Weare them, betray with them; Whore ſtill,
Paint till a horſe may myre vpon your face:
A pox of wrinkles.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: Well, more Gold, what then?
Beleeue’t that wee’l do any thing for Gold.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Conſumptions ſowe
In hollow bones of man, ſtrike their ſharpe ſhinnes,
And marre mens ſpurring. Cracke the Lawyers voyce,
That he may neuer more falſe Title pleade,
Nor ſound his Quillets ſhrilly: Hoare the Flamen,
That ſcold’ſt againſt the quality of ﬂeſh,
And not beleeues himſelfe. Downe with the Noſe,
Downe with it ﬂat, take the Bridge quite away
Of him, that his particular to foreſee
Smels from the generall weale. Make curl’d pate Rufﬁans bald
And let the vnſcarr’d Braggerts of the Warre
Deriue ſome paine from you. Plague all,
That your Aƈtiuity may defeate and quell
The ſourſe of all Ereƈtion. There’s more Gold.
Do you damne others, and let this damne you,
And ditches graue you all.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: More counſell with more Money, bounteous
Timon.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: More whore, more Miſcheefe ﬁrſt, I haue gi-
uen you earneſt.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: Strike vp the Drum towardes Athens, farewell
Timon: if I thriue well, Ile viſit thee againe.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: If I hope well, Ile neuer ſee thee more.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: I neuer did thee harme.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Yes, thou ſpok’ſt well of me.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: Call’ſt thou that harme?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Men dayly ﬁnde it. Get thee away,
And take thy Beagles with thee.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: We but offend him, ſtrike.Exeunt.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: That Nature being ſicke of mans vnkindneſſe
Should yet be hungry: Common Mother, thou
Whoſe wombe vnmeaſureable, and inﬁnite breſt
Teemes and feeds all: whoſe ſelfeſame Mettle
Whereof thy proud Childe (arrogant man) is puﬅ,
Engenders the blacke Toad, and Adder blew,
The gilded Newt, and eyeleſſe venom’d Worme,
With all th’ abhorred Births below Criſpe Heauen,
Whereon Hyperions quickning ﬁre doth ſhine:
Yeeld him, who all the humane Sonnes do hate,
From foorth thy plenteous boſome, one poore roote:
Enſeare thy Fertile and Conceptious wombe,
Let it no more bring out ingratefull man.
Gœ great with Tygers, Dragons, Wolues, and Beares,
Teeme with new Monſters, whom thy vpward face
Hath to the Marbled Manſion all aboue
Neuer preſented. O, a Root, deare thankes:
Dry vp thy Marrowes, Vines, and Plough-torne Leas,
Whereof ingratefull man with Licouriſh draughts
And Morſels Vnƈtious, greaſes his pure minde,
That from it all Conſideration ſlippes—
More man? Plague, plague.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: I was direƈted hither. Men report,
Thou doſt affeƈt my Manners, and doſt vſe them.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: ’Tis then, becauſe thou doſt not keepe a dogge
Whom I would imitate. Conſumption catch thee.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: This is in thee a Nature but infeƈted,
A poore vnmanly Melancholly ſprung
From change of future. Why this Spade? this place?
This Slaue-like Habit, and theſe lookes of Care?
Thy Flatterers yet weare Silke, drinke Wine, lye ſoﬅ,
Hugge their diſeas’d Perfumes, and haue forgot
That euer Timon was. Shame not theſe Woods,
By putting on the cunning of a Carper.
Be thou a Flatterer now, and ſeeke to thriue
By that which ha’s vndone thee; hindge thy knee,
And let his very breath whom thou’lt obſerue
Blow off thy Cap: praiſe his moſt vicious ſtraine,
And call it excellent: thou waſt told thus:
Thou gau’ſt thine eares (like Tapſters, that bad welcom)
To Knaues, and all approachers: ’Tis moſt iuſt
That thou turne Raſcall, had’ſt thou wealth againe,
Raſcals ſhould haue’t. Do not aſſume my likeneſſe.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Were I like thee, I’de throw away my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Thou haſt caſt away thy ſelfe, being like thy ſelf
A Madman ſo long, now a Foole: what think’ſt
That the bleake ayre, thy boyſterous Chamberlaine
Will put thy ſhirt on warme? Will theſe moyſt Trees,
That haue out-liu’d the Eagle, page thy heeles
And skip when thou point’ſt out? Will the cold brooke
Candied with Ice, Cawdle thy Morning taſte
To cure thy o’re-nights ſurfet? Call the Creatures,
Whoſe naked Natures liue in all the ſpight
Of wrekefull Heauen, whoſe bare vnhouſed Trunkes,
To the conﬂiƈting Elements expos’d
Anſwer meere Nature: bid them ﬂatter thee.
O thou ſhalt ﬁnde.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: A Foole of thee: depart.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: I loue thee better now, then ere I did.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I hate thee worſe.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Why?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Thou ﬂatter’ſt miſery.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: I ﬂatter not, but ſay thou art a Caytiffe.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Why do’ſt thou ſeeke me out?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: To vex thee.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Alwayes a Villaines Ofﬁce, or a Fooles.
Doſt pleaſe thy ſelfe in’t?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: I.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: What, a Knaue too?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: If thou did’ſt put this ſowre cold habit on
To caſtigate thy pride, ’twere well: but thou
Doſt it enforcedly: Thou’dſt Courtier be againe
Wert thou not Beggar: willing miſery
Out-liues: incertaine pompe, is crown’d before:
The one is ﬁlling ſtill, neuer compleat:
The other, at high wiſh: beſt ſtate Contentleſſe,
Hath a diſtraƈted and moſt wretched being,
Worſe then the worſt, Content.
Thou ſhould’ſt deſire to dye, being miſerable.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Not by his breath, that is more miſerable.
Thou art a Slaue, whom Fortunes tender arme
With fauour neuer claſpt: but bred a Dogge.
Had’ſt thou like vs from our ﬁrſt ſwath proceeded,
The ſweet degrees that this breefe world affords,
To ſuch as may the paſſiue drugges of it
Freely command’ſt: thou would’ſt haue plung’d thy ſelf
In generall Riot, melted downe thy youth
In different beds of Luſt, and neuer learn’d
The Icie precepts of reſpeƈt, but followed
The Sugred game before thee. But my ſelfe,
Who had the world as my Confeƈtionarie,
The mouthes, the tongues, the eyes, and hearts of men,
At duty more then I could frame employment;
That numberleſſe vpon me ſtucke, as leaues
Do on the Oake, haue with one Winters bruſh
Fell from their boughes, and leﬅ me open, bare,
For euery ſtorme that blowes. I to beare this,
That neuer knew but better, is ſome burthen:
Thy Nature, did commence in ſufferance, Time
Hath made thee hard in’t. Why ſhould’ſt ӳ hate Men?
They neuer ﬂatter’d thee. What haſt thou giuen?
If thou wilt curſe; thy Father (that poore ragge)
Muſt be thy ſubieƈt; who in ſpight put ſtuffe
To ſome ſhee-Begger, and compounded thee
Poore Rogue, hereditary. Hence, be gone,
If thou hadſt not bene borne the worſt of men,
Thou hadſt bene a Knaue and Flatterer.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Art thou proud yet?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I, that I am not thee.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: I, that I was no Prodigall.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I, that I am one now.
Were all the wealth I haue ſhut vp in thee,
I’ld giue thee leaue to hang it. Get thee gone:
That the whole life of Athens were in this,
Thus would I eate it.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Heere, I will mend thy Feaſt.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Firſt mend thy company, take away thy ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: So I ſhall mend mine owne, by’th’ lacke of thine

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: ’Tis not well mended ſo, it is but botcht;
If not, I would it were.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: What would’ſt thou haue to Athens?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Thee thither in a whirlewind: if thou wilt,
Tell them there I haue Gold, looke, ſo I haue.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Heere is no vſe for Gold.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: The beſt, and trueſt:
For heere it ſleepes, and do’s no hyred harme.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Where lyeſt a nights Timon?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Vnder that’s aboue me.
Where feed’ſt thou a-dayes Apemantus?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Where my ſtomacke ﬁndes meate, or rather
where I eate it.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Would poyſon were obedient, & knew my mind

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Where would’ſt thou ſend it?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: To ſawce thy diſhes.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: The middle of Humanity thou neuer kneweſt,
but the extremitie of both ends. When thou waſt in thy
Gilt, and thy Perfume, they mockt thee for too much
Curioſitie: in thy Ragges thou know’ſt none, but art de-
ſpis’d for the contrary. There’s a medler for thee, eate it.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: On what I hate, I feed not.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Do’ſt hate a Medler?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I, though it looke like thee.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: And th’hadſt hated Medlers ſooner, ӳ ſhould’ſt
haue loued thy ſelfe better now. What man didd’ſt thou
euer know vnthriﬅ, that was beloued aﬅer his meanes!

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Who without thoſe meanes thou talk’ſt of, didſt
thou euer know belou’d?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: My ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I vnderſtand thee: thou had’ſt ſome meanes to
keepe a Dogge.

speech.speaker: Apem.
speech.line: What things in the world canſt thou neereſt
compare to thy Flatterers?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Women neereſt, but men: men are the things
themſelues. What would’ſt thou do with the world A-
pemantus, if it lay in thy power?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Giue it the Beaſts, to be rid of the men.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Would’ſt thou haue thy ſelfe fall in the confu-
ſion of men, and remaine a Beaſt with the Beaſts.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: I Timon.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: A beaſtly Ambition, which the Goddes graunt
thee t’attaine to. If thou wert the Lyon, the Fox would
beguile thee. if thou wert the Lambe, the Foxe would
eate thee: if thou wert the Fox, the Lion would ſuſpeƈt
thee, when peraduenture thou wert accus’d by the Aſſe:
If thou wert the Aſſe, thy dulneſſe would torment thee;
and ſtill thou liu’dſt but as a Breakefaſt to the Wolfe. If
thou wert the Wolfe, thy greedineſſe would afﬂiƈt thee,
& oﬅ thou ſhould’ſt hazard thy life for thy dinner. Wert
thou the Vnicorne, pride and wrath would confound
thee, and make thine owne ſelfe the conqueſt of thy fury.
Wert thou a Beare, thou would’ſt be kill’d by the Horſe:
wert thou a Horſe, thou would’ſt be ſeaz’d by the Leo-
pard: wert thou a Leopard, thou wert Germane to the
Lion, and the ſpottes of thy Kindred, were Iurors on thy
life. All thy ſafety were remotion, and thy defence ab-
ſence. What Beaſt could’ſt thou bee, that were not ſub-
ieƈt to a Beaſt: and what a Beaſt art thou already, that
ſeeſt not thy loſſe in transformation.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: If thou could’ſt pleaſe me
With ſpeaking to me, thou might’ſt
Haue hit vpon it heere.
The Commonwealth of Athens, is become
A Forreſt of Beaſts.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: How ha’s the Aſſe broke the wall, that thou art
out of the Citie.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Yonder comes a Pœt and a Painter:
The plague of Company light vpon thee:
I will feare to catch it, and giue way.
When I know not what elſe to do,
Ile ſee thee againe.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: When there is nothing liuing but thee,
Thou ſhalt be welcome.
I had rather be a Beggers Dogge,
Then Apemantus.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Thou art the Cap
Of all the Fooles aliue.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Would thou wert cleane enough
To ſpit vpon.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: A plague on thee,
Thou art too bad to curſe.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: All Villaines
That do ſtand by thee, are pure.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: There is no Leproſie,
But what thou ſpeak’ſt.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: If I name thee, Ile beate thee;
But I ſhould infeƈt my hands.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: I would my tongue
Could rot them off.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Away thou iſſue of a mangie dogge,
Choller dœs kill me,
That thou art aliue, I ſwoond to ſee thee.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Would thou would’ſt burſt.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Away thou tedious Rogue, I am ſorry I ſhall
loſe a ſtone by thee.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Beaſt.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Slaue.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Toad.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Rogue, Rogue, Rogue.
I am ſicke of this falſe world, and will loue nought
But euen the meere neceſſities vpon’t:
Then Timon preſently prepare thy graue:
Lye where the light Fome of the Sea may beate
Thy graue ſtone dayly, make thine Epitaph,
That death in me, at others liues may laugh.
O thou ſweete King-killer, and deare diuorce
Twixt naturall Sunne and ﬁre: thou bright deﬁler
Of Himens pureſt bed, thou valiant Mars,
Thou euer, yong, freſh, loued, and delicate woœr,
Whoſe bluſh doth thawe the conſecrated Snow
That lyes on Dians lap.
Thou viſible God,
That ſouldreſt cloſe Impoſſibilities,
And mak’ſt them kiſſe; that ſpeak’ſt with euerie Tongue
To euerie purpoſe: O thou touch of hearts,
Thinke thy ſlaue-man rebels, and by thy vertue
Set them into confounding oddes, that Beaſts
May haue the world in Empire.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Would ’twere ſo,
But not till I am dead. Ile ſay th’haſt Gold:
Thou wilt be throng’d too ſhortly.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Throng’d too?

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: I.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Thy backe I prythee.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Liue, and loue thy miſery.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Long liue ſo, and ſo dye. I am quit.

speech.speaker: Ape.
speech.line: Mo things like men,
Eate Timon, and abhorre then.Exit Apeman.
Where ſhould he haue this Gold? It is ſome poore
Fragment, ſome ſlender Ort of his remainder: the meere
want of Gold, and the falling from of his Friendes, droue
him into this Melancholly.
It is nois’d
He hath a maſſe of Treaſure.
Let vs make the aſſay vpon him, if he care not for’t,
he will ſupply vs eaſily: if he couetouſly reſerue it, how
ſhall’s get it?
True: for he beares it not about him:
’Tis hid.
Is not this hee?

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Where?
’Tis his deſcription.
He? I know him.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Saue thee Timon.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Now Theeues.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Soldiers, not Theeues.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Both too, and womens Sonnes.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: We are not Theeues, but men
That much do want.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Your greateſt want is, you want much of meat:
Why ſhould you want? Behold, the Earth hath Rootes:
Within this Mile breake forth a hundred Springs:
The Oakes beare Maſt, the Briars Scarlet Heps,
The bounteous Huſwife Nature, on each buſh,
Layes her full Meſſe before you. Want? why Want?
We cannot liue on Graſſe, on Berries, Water,
As Beaſts, and Birds, and Fiſhes.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Nor on the Beaſts themſelues, the Birds & Fiſhes,
You muſt eate men. Yet thankes I muſt you con,
That you are Theeues profeſt: that you worke not
In holier ſhapes: For there is boundleſſe Theﬅ
In limited Profeſſions. Raſcall Theeues
Heere’s Gold. Go, ſucke the ſubtle blood o’th’ Grape,
Till the high Feauor ſeeth your blood to froth,
And ſo ſcape hanging. Trust not the Phyſitian,
His Antidotes are poyſon, and he ſlayes
Mœ then you Rob: Take wealth, and liues together,
Do Villaine do, ſince you proteſt to doo’t.
Like Workemen, Ile example you with Theeuery:
The Sunnes a Theefe, and with his great attraƈtion
Robbes the vaſte Sea. The Moones an arrant Theefe,
And her pale ﬁre, ſhe ſnatches from the Sunne.
The Seas a Theefe, whoſe liquid Surge, reſolues
The Moone into Salt teares. The Earth’s a Theefe,
That feeds and breeds by a compoſture ſtolne
From gen’rall excrement: each thing’s a Theefe.
The Lawes, your curbe and whip, in their rough power
Ha’s vncheck’d Theﬅ. Loue not your ſelues, away,
Rob one another, there’s more Gold, cut throates,
All that you meete are Theeues: to Athens go,
Breake open ſhoppes, nothing can you ſteale
But Theeues do looſe it: ſteale leſſe, for this I giue you,
And Gold confound you howſœre: Amen.
Has almoſt charm’d me from my Profeſſion, by per-
ſwading me to it.
’Tis in the malice of mankinde, that he thus aduiſes
vs not to haue vs thriue in our myſtery.
Ile beleeue him as an Enemy,
And giue ouer my Trade.
Let vs ﬁrſt ſee peace in Athens, there is no time ſo
miſerable, but a man may be true.Exit Theeues.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Oh you Gods! Is yon’d deſpis’d and ruinous man my Lord?
Full of decay and fayling? Oh Monument
And wonder of good deeds, euilly beſtow’d!
What an alteration of Honor has deſp’rate want made?
What vilder thing vpon the earth, then Friends,
Who can bring Nobleſt mindes, to baſeſt ends.
How rarely dœs it meete with this times guiſe,
When man was wiſht to loue his Enemies:
Grant I may euer loue, and rather woo
Thoſe that would miſcheefe me, then thoſe that doo.
Has caught me in his eye, I will preſent my honeſt griefe
vnto him; and as my Lord, ſtill ſerue him with my life.
My deereſt Maſter.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Away: what art thou?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Haue you forgot me, Sir?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Why doſt aske that? I haue forgot all men.
Then, if thou grunt’ſt, th’art a man.
I haue forgot thee.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: An honeſt poore ſeruant of yours.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Then I know thee not:
I neuer had honeſt man about me, I all
I kept were Knaues, to ſerue in meate to Villaines.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: The Gods are witneſſe,
Neu’r did poore Steward weare a truer greefe
For his vndone Lord, then mine eyes for you.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: What, doſt thou weepe?
Come neerer, then I loue thee
Becauſe thou art a woman, and diſclaim’ſt
Flinty mankinde: whoſe eyes do neuer giue,
But thorow Luſt and Laughter: pittie’s ſleeping:
Strange times ý weepe with laughing, not with weeping.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: I begge of you to know me, good my Lord,
T’ accept my greefe, and whil’ſt this poore wealth laſts,
To entertaine me as your Steward ſtill.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Had I a Steward
So true, ſo iuſt, and now ſo comfortable?
It almoſt turnes my dangerous Nature wilde.
Let me behold thy face: Surely, this man
Was borne of woman.
Forgiue my generall, and exceptleſſe raſhneſſe
You perpetuall ſober Gods. I do proclaime
One honeſt man: Miſtake me not, but one:
No more I pray, and hee’s a Steward.
How faine would I haue hated all mankinde,
And thou redeem’ſt thy ſelfe. But all ſaue thee,
I fell with Curſes.
Me thinkes thou art more honeſt now, then wiſe:
For, by oppreſſing and betraying mee,
Thou might’ſt haue ſooner got another Seruice:
For many ſo arriue at ſecond Maſters,
Vpon their ﬁrſt Lords necke. But tell me true,
(For I muſt euer doubt, though ne’re ſo ſure)
Is not thy kindneſſe ſubtle, couetous,
If not a Vſuring kindneſſe, and as rich men deale Guiﬅs,
Expeƈting in returne twenty for one?

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: No my moſt worthy Maſter, in whoſe breſt
Doubt, and ſuſpeƈt (alas) are plac’d too late:
You ſhould haue fear’d falſe times, when you did Feaſt.
Suſpeƈt ſtill comes, where an eſtate is leaſt.
That which I ſhew, Heauen knowes, is meerely Loue,
Dutie, and Zeale, to your vnmatched minde;
Care of your Food and Liuing, and beleeue it,
My moſt Honour’d Lord,
For any beneﬁt that points to mee,
Either in hope, or preſent, I’de exchange
For this one wiſh, that you had power and wealth
To requite me, by making rich your ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Looke thee, ’tis ſo: thou ſingly honeſt man,
Heere take: the Gods out of my miſerie
Ha’s ſent thee Treaſure. Go, liue rich and happy,
But thus condition’d: Thou ſhalt build from men:
Hate all, curſe all, ſhew Charity to none,
But let the famiſht ﬂeſh ſlide from the Bone,
Ere thou releeue the Begger. Giue to dogges
What thou denyeſt to men. Let Priſons ſwallow ’em,
Debts wither ’em to nothing, be men like blaſted woods
And may Diſeaſes licke vp their falſe bloods,
And ſo farewell, and thriue.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: O let me ſtay, and comfort you, my Maſter.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: If thou hat’ſt Curſes
Stay not: ﬂye, whil’ſt thou art bleſt and free:
Ne’re ſee thou man, and let me ne’re ſee thee.Exit

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: As I tooke note of the place, it cannot be farre
where he abides.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: What’s to be thought of him?
Dœs the Rumor hold for true,
That hee’s ſo full of Gold?

speech.speaker: Painter.
speech.line: Certaine.
Alcibiades reports it: Phrinica and Timandylo
Had Gold of him. He likewiſe enrich’d
Poore ſtragling Souldiers, with great quantity.
’Tis ſaide, he gaue vnto his Steward
A mighty ſumme.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: Then this breaking of his,
Ha’s beene but a Try for his Friends?

speech.speaker: Painter.
speech.line: Nothing elſe:
You ſhall ſee him a Palme in Athens againe,
And ﬂouriſh with the higheſt:
Therefore, ’tis not amiſſe, we tender our loues
To him, in this ſuppos’d diſtreſſe of his:
It will ſhew honeſtly in vs,
And is very likely, to loade our purpoſes
With what they trauaile for,
If it be a iuſt and true report, that gœs
Of his hauing.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: What haue you now
To preſent vnto him?

speech.speaker: Painter.
speech.line: Nothing at this time
But my Viſitation: onely I will promiſe him
An excellent Peece.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: I muſt ſerue him ſo too;
Tell him of an intent that’s comming toward him.

speech.speaker: Painter.
speech.line: Good as the beſt.
Promiſing, is the verie Ayre o’th’ Time;
It opens the eyes of Expeƈtation.
Performance, is euer the duller for his aƈte,
And but in the plainer and ſimpler kinde of people,
The deede of Saying is quite out of vſe.
To Promiſe, is moſt Courtly and faſhionable;
Performance, is a kinde of Will or Teſtament
Which argues a great ſickneſſe in his iudgement
That makes it.

speech.speaker: Timon.
speech.line: Excellent Workeman,
Thou canſt not paint a man ſo badde
As is thy ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: I am thinking
What I ſhall ſay I haue prouided for him:
It muſt be a perſonating of himſelfe:
A Satyre againſt the ſoﬅneſſe of Proſperity,
With a Diſcouerie of the inﬁnite Flatteries
That follow youth and opulencie.

speech.speaker: Timon.
speech.line: Muſt thou needes
Stand for a Villaine in thine owne Worke?
Wilt thou whip thine owne faults in other men?
Do ſo, I haue Gold for thee.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: Nay let’s ſeeke him.
Then do we ſinne againſt our owne eſtate,
When we may proﬁt meete, and come too late.

speech.speaker: Painter.
speech.line: True:
When the day ſerues before blacke-corner’d night;
Finde what thou want’ſt, by free and offer’d light.
Come.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Ile meete you at the turne:
What a Gods Gold, that he is worſhipt
In a baſer Temple, then where Swine feede?
’Tis thou that rigg’ſt the Barke, and plow’ſt the Fome,
Setleſt admired reuerence in a Slaue,
To thee be worſhipt, and thy Saints for aye:
Be crown’d with Plagues, that thee alone obay.
Fit I meet them.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: Haile worthy Timon.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: Our late Noble Maſter.

speech.speaker: Timon.
speech.line: Haue I once liu’d
To ſee two honeſt men?

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: Sir:
Hauing oﬅen of your open Bounty taſted,
Hearing you were retyr’d, your Friends falne off,
Whoſe thankeleſſe Natures (O abhorred Spirits)
Not all the Whippes of Heauen, are large enough.
What, to you,
Whoſe Starre-like Nobleneſſe gaue life and inﬂuence
To their whole being? I am rapt, and cannot couet
The monſtrous bulke of this Ingratitude
With any ſize of words.

speech.speaker: Timon.
speech.line: Let it go,
Naked men may ſee’t the better:
You that are honeſt, by being what you are,
Make them beſt ſeene, and knowne.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: He, and my ſelfe
Haue trauail’d in the great ſhowre of your guiﬅs,
And ſweetly felt it.

speech.speaker: Timon.
speech.line: I, you are honeſt man.

speech.speaker: Painter.
speech.line: We are hither come
To offer you our ſeruice.

speech.speaker: Timon.
speech.line: Moſt honeſt men:
Why how ſhall I requite you?
Can you eate Roots, and drinke cold water, no?

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: What we can do,
Wee’l do to do you ſeruice.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Y’are honeſt men,
Y’haue heard that I haue Gold,
I am ſure you haue, ſpeake truth, y’are honeſt men.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: So it is ſaid my Noble Lord, but therefore
Came not my Friend, nor I.

speech.speaker: Timon.
speech.line: Good honeſt men: Thou draw’ſt a counterfet
Beſt in all Athens, th’art indeed the beſt,
Thou counterfet’ſt moſt liuely.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: So, ſo, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: E’ne ſo ſir as I ſay. And for thy ﬁƈtion,
Why thy Verſe ſwels with ſtuffe ſo ﬁne and ſmooth,
That thou art euen Naturall in thine Art.
But for all this (my honeſt Natur’d friends)
I muſt needs ſay you haue a little fault,
Marry ’tis not monſtrous in you, neither wiſh I
You take much paines to mend.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: Beſeech your Honour
To make it knowne to vs.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: You’l take it ill.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: Moſt thankefully, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Timon.
speech.line: Will you indeed?

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: Doubt it not worthy Lord.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: There’s neuer a one of you but truſts a Knaue,
That mightily deceiues you.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: Do we, my Lord?

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I, and you heare him cogge,
See him diſſemble,
Know his groſſe patchery, loue him, feede him,
Keepe in your boſome, yet remaine aſſur’d
That he’s a made-vp-Villaine.

speech.speaker: Pain.
speech.line: I know none ſuch, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Pœt.
speech.line: Nor I.

speech.speaker: Timon.
speech.line: Looke you,
I loue you well, Ile giue you Gold
Rid me theſe Villaines from your companies;
Hang them, or ſtab them, drowne them in a draught,
Confound them by ſome courſe, and come to me,
Ile giue you Gold enough.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: Name them my Lord, let’s know them.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: You that way, and you this:
But two in Company:
Each man a part, all ſingle, and alone,
Yet an arch Villaine keepes him company:
If where thou art, two Villaines ſhall not be,
Come not neere him. If thou would’ſt not recide
But where one Villaine is, then him abandon.
Hence, packe, there’s Gold, you came for Gold ye ſlaues:
You haue worke for me; there’s payment, hence,
You are an Alcumiſt, make Gold of that:
Out Raſcall dogges.Exeunt

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: It is vaine that you would ſpeake with Timon:
For he is ſet ſo onely to himſelfe,
That nothing but himſelfe, which lookes like man,
Is friendly with him.

speech.speaker: 1.Sen.
speech.line: Bring vs to his Caue.
It is our part and promiſe to th’ Athenians
To ſpeake with Timon.

speech.speaker: 2.Sen.
speech.line: At all times alike
Men are not ſtill the ſame: ’twas Time and Greefes
That fram’d him thus. Time with his fairer hand,
Offering the Fortunes of his former dayes,
The former man may make him: bring vs to him
And chanc’d it as it may.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Heere is his Caue:
Peace and content be heere. Lord Timon, Timon,
Looke out, and ſpeake to Friends: Th’ Athenians
By two of their moſt reuerend Senate greet thee:
Speake to them Noble Timon.

act.stagedir: Enter Timon out of his Caue.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Thou Sunne that comforts burne,
Speake and be hang’d:
For each true word, a bliſter, and each falſe
Be as a Cantherizing to the root o’th’ Tongue,
Conſuming it with ſpeaking.
Worthy Timon.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Of none but ſuch as you,
And you of Timon.
The Senators of Athens, greet thee Timon.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I thanke them,
And would ſend them backe the plague,
Could I but catch it for them.
O forget
What we are ſorry for our ſelues in thee:
The Senators, with one conſent of loue,
Intreate thee backe to Athens, who haue thought
On ſpeciall Dignities, which vacant lye
For thy beſt vſe and wearing.
They confeſſe
Toward thee, forgetfulneſſe too generall groſſe;
Which now the publike Body, which doth ſildome
Play the re-canter, feeling in it ſelfe
A lacke of Timons ayde, hath ſince withall
Of it owne fall, reſtraining ayde to Timon,
And ſend forth vs, to make their ſorrowed render,
Together, with a recompence more fruitfull
Then their offence can weigh downe by the Dramme,
I euen ſuch heapes and ſummes of Loue and Wealth,
As ſhall to thee blot out, what wrongs were theirs,
And write in thee the ﬁgures of their loue,
Euer to read them thine.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: You witch me in it;
Surprize me to the very brinke of teares;
Lend me a Fooles heart, and a womans eyes,
And Ile beweepe theſe comforts, worthy Senators.
Therefore ſo pleaſe thee to returne with vs,
And of our Athens, thine and ours to take
The Captainſhip, thou ſhalt be met with thankes,
Allowed with abſolute power, and thy good name
Liue with Authoritie: ſo ſoone we ſhall driue backe
Of Alcibiades th’approaches wild,
Who like a Bore too ſauage, doth root vp
His Countries peace.
And ſhakes his threatning Sword
Againſt the walles of Athens.
Therefore Timon.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Well ſir, I will: therefore I will ſir thus:
If Alcibiades kill my Countrymen,
Let Alcibiades know this of Timon,
That Timon cares not. But if he ſacke faire Athens,
And take our goodly aged men by’th’ Beards,
Giuing our holy Virgins to the ſtaine
Of contumelious, beaſtly, mad-brain’d warre:
Then let him know, and tell him Timon ſpeakes it,
In pitty of our aged, and our youth,
I cannot chooſe but tell him that I care not,
And let him tak’t at worſt: For their Kniues care not,
While you haue throats to anſwer. For my ſelfe,
There’s not a whittle, in th’ vnruly Campe,
But I do prize it at my loue, before
The reuerends Throat in Athens. So I leaue you
To the proteƈtion of the proſperous Gods,
As Theeues to Keepers.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Stay not, all’s in vaine.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Why I was writing of my Epitaph,
It will be ſeene to morrow. My long ſickneſſe
Of Health, and Liuing, now begins to mend,
And nothing brings me all things. Go, liue ſtill,
Be Alcibiades your plague; you his,
And laſt ſo long enough.
We ſpeake in vaine.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: But yet I loue my Country, and am not
One that reioyces in the common wracke,
As common bruite doth put it.
That’s well ſpoke.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Commend me to my louing Countreymen.
Theſe words become your lippes as they paſſe tho-
row them.
And enter in our eares, like great Triumphers
In their applauding gates.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Commend me to them,
And tell them, that to eaſe them of their greefes,
Their feares of Hoſtile ſtrokes, their Aches loſſes,
Their pangs of Loue, with other incident throwes
That Natures fragile Veſſell doth ſuſtaine
In lifes vncertaine voyage, I will ſome kindnes do them,
Ile teach them to preuent wilde Alcibiades wrath.
I like this well, he will returne againe.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: I haue a Tree which growes heere in my Cloſe,
That mine owne vſe inuites me to cut downe,
And ſhortly muſt I fell it. Tell my Friends,
Tell Athens, in the ſequence of degree,
From high to low throughout, that who ſo pleaſe
To ſtop Afﬂiƈtion, let him take his haſte;
Come hither ere my Tree hath felt the Axe,
And hang himſelfe. I pray you do my greeting.

speech.speaker: Stew.
speech.line: Trouble him no further, thus you ſtill ſhall
Finde him.

speech.speaker: Tim.
speech.line: Come not to me againe, but ſay to Athens,
Timon hath made his euerlaſting Manſion
Vpon the Beached Verge of the ſalt Flood,
Who once a day with his emboſſed Froth
The turbulent Surge ſhall couer; thither come,
And let my graue-ſtone be your Oracle:
Lippes, let foure words go by, and Language end:
What is amiſſe, Plague and Infeƈtion mend.
Graues onely be mens workes, and Death their gaine;
Sunne, hide thy Beames, Timon hath done his Raigne.
His diſcontents are vnremoueably coupled to Na-
ture.
Our hope in him is dead: let vs returne,
And ſtraine what other meanes is leﬅ vnto vs
In our deere perill.
It requires ſwiﬅ foot.Exeunt.

act.stagedir: Enter two other Senators, with a Meſſenger.

speech.line: Thou haſt painfully diſcouer’d: are his Files
As full as thy report?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: I haue ſpoke the leaſt.
Beſides his expedition promiſes preſent approach.
We ſtand much hazard, if they bring not Timon.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: I met a Currier, one mine ancient Friend,
Whom though in generall part we were oppos’d,
Yet our old loue made a particular force,
And made vs ſpeake like Friends. This man was riding
From Alcibiades to Timons Caue,
With Letters of intreaty, which imported
His Fellowſhip i’th’ cauſe againſt your City,
In part for his ſake mou’d.
Heere come our Brothers.
No talke of Timon, nothing of him expeƈt,
The Enemies Drumme is heard, and fearefull ſcouring
Doth choake the ayre with duſt: In, and prepare,
Ours is the fall I feare, our Fœs the Snare.Exeunt

act.stagedir: Enter a Souldier in the Woods, ſeeking Timon.

speech.speaker: Sol.
speech.line: By all deſcription this ſhould be the place.
Whoſe heere? Speake hoa. No anſwer? What is this?
Tymon is dead, who hath out-ſtretcht his ſpan,
Some Beaſt reade this; There do’s not liue a Man.
Dead ſure, and this his Graue, what’s on this Tomb,
I cannot read: the Charraƈter Ile take with wax,
Our Captaine hath in euery Figure skill;
An ag’d Interpreter, though yong in dayes:
Before proud Athens hee’s ſet downe by this,
Whoſe fall the marke of his Ambition is. Exit.

act.stagedir: Trumpets ſound. Enter Alcibiades with his Powers before Athens.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: Sound to this Coward, and laſciuious Towne,
Our terrible approach.
speech.stagedir: The Senators appeare vpon the wals.
speech.line: Till now you haue gone on, and ﬁll’d the time
With all Licentious meaſure, making your willes
The ſcope of Iuſtice. Till now, my ſelfe and ſuch
As ſlept within the ſhadow of your power
Haue wander’d with our trauerſt Armes, and breath’d
Our ſufferance vainly: Now the time is ﬂuſh,
When crouching Marrow in the bearer ſtrong
Cries (of it ſelfe) no more: Now breathleſſe wrong,
Shall ſit and pant in your great Chaires of eaſe,
And purſie Inſolence ſhall breake his winde
With feare and horrid ﬂight.

speech.speaker: 1.Sen.
speech.line: Noble, and young;
When thy ﬁrſt greefes were but a meere conceit,
Ere thou had’ſt power, or we had cauſe of feare,
We ſent to thee, to giue thy rages Balme,
To wipe out our Ingratitude, with Loues
Aboue their quantitie.
So did we woœ
Tranſformed Timon, to our Citties loue
By humble Meſſage, and by promiſt meanes:
We were not all vnkinde, nor all deſerue
The common ſtroke of warre.
Theſe walles of ours,
Were not ereƈted by their hands, from whom
You haue receyu’d your greefe: Nor are they ſuch,
That theſe great Towres, Trophees, & Schools ſhold fall
For priuate faults in them.
Nor are they liuing
Who were the motiues that you ﬁrſt went out,
(Shame that they wanted, cunning in exceſſe)
Hath broke their hearts. March, Noble Lord,
Into our City with thy Banners ſpred,
By decimation and a tythed death;
If thy Reuenges hunger for that Food
Which Nature loathes, take thou the deſtin’d tenth,
And by the hazard of the ſpotted dye,
Let dye the ſpotted.
All haue not offended:
For thoſe that were, it is not ſquare to take
On thoſe that are, Reuenge: Crimes, like Lands
Are not inherited, then deere Countryman,
Bring in thy rankes, but leaue without thy rage,
Spare thy Athenian Cradle, and thoſe Kin
Which in the bluſter of thy wrath muſt fall
With thoſe that haue offended, like a Shepheard,
Approach the Fold, and cull th’infeƈted forth,
But kill not altogether.
What thou wilt,
Thou rather ſhalt inforce it with thy ſmile,
Then hew too’t, with thy Sword.
Set but thy foot
Againſt our rampyr’d gates, and they ſhall ope:
So thou wilt ſend thy gentle heart before,
To ſay thou’t enter Friendly.
Throw thy Gloue,
Or any Token of thine Honour elſe,
That thou wilt vſe the warres as thy redreſſe,
And not as our Confuſion: All thy Powers
Shall make their harbour in our Towne, till wee
Haue ſeal’d thy full deſire.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: Then there’s my Gloue,
Defend and open your vncharged Ports,
Thoſe Enemies of Timons, and mine owne
Whom you your ſelues ſhall ſet out for reproofe,
Fall and no more; and to attone your feares
With my more Noble meaning, not a man
Shall paſſe his quarter, or offend the ſtreame
Of Regular Iuſtice in your Citties bounds,
But ſhall be remedied to your publique Lawes
At heauieſt anſwer.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: ’Tis moſt Nobly ſpoken.

speech.speaker: Alc.
speech.line: Deſcend, and keepe your words.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: My Noble Generall, Timon is dead,
Entomb’d vpon the very hemme o’th’ Sea,
And on his Graueſtone, this Inſculpture which
With wax I brought away: whoſe ſoﬅ Impreſſion
Interprets for my poore ignorance.

line.italic: Heere lies a wretched Coarſe, of wretched Soule bereﬅ,
Seek not my name: A Plague conſume you, wicked Caitifs leﬅ:
Heere lye I Timon, who aliue, all liuing men did hate,
Paſſe by, and curſe thy ﬁll, but paſſe and ſtay not here thy gate.

speech.line: Theſe well expreſſe in thee thy latter ſpirits:
Though thou abhorrd’ſt in vs our humane griefes,
Scornd’ſt our Braines ﬂow, and thoſe our droplets, which
From niggard Nature fall; yet Rich Conceit
Taught thee to make vaſt Neptune weepe for aye
On thy low Graue, on faults forgiuen. Dead
Is Noble Timon, of whoſe Memorie
Heereaﬅer more. Bring me into your Citie,
And I will vſe the Oliue, with my Sword:
Make war breed peace; make peace ſtint war, make each
Preſcribe to other, as each others Leach.
Let our Drummes ſtrike.Exeunt.

personae.persona: Ventigius. one of Tymons falſe Friends.
